            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	

<h3 class="heading">Careers with a <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/" target="_blank">Philosophy Degree</a> </h3>





<script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.google.com/jsapi"></script>
<p>
A degree in Philosophy is well regarded by a wide range of recruiters. Throughout the degree, students acquire high level skills in analysis, independent critical thinking, and the communication of ideas.
</p>

    
        
    

    

    
        
    

    

    

    
        
    
<div style='width:100%; overflow:hidden;'>

<div style='float:left; margin-right: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;'>

<script type="text/javascript" language="javascript"
src="http://widgets.thecareersgroup.co.uk/graduatesbetweenperiodchartwidget.jss?id=chart1&instid=0149&yearstogoback=1&title=&showkeyfacts=false&width=240&height=190&theme=ucl_borderless&departments=PHILOSOPHY
&backgroundcolor=fff&includetitle=false&legendposition=none">
</script>
<br/>
<!-- hide this
<div style="margin-top:10px;padding-top:10px;padding-bottom:5px;">
Undergraduate UK and EU students only
</div>-->



</div>

<div style='float:left;margin-left: 5px; margin-bottom: 5px;'>

<script type="text/javascript" language="javascript"
src="http://widgets.thecareersgroup.co.uk/graduatesbetweenperiodkeyfacts.jss?id=keyfact1&instid=0149&yearstogoback=1&title=UCL Philosophy Graduates&width=240&height=70&theme=ucl&departments=PHILOSOPHY&backgroundcolor=fff&includetitle=true">
</script>

<br />

<div style='clear:both'></div>
<div style="padding-top:5px;padding-bottom:5px;">
Data gathered 6 months after graduation.<br/>Undergraduate UK and EU students only.
</div>
<div style="border: none; width: 220px; height: 80px; padding: 5px;">

<div style="height: 10px; width: 10px; background-color: #DC3912; float: left;margin-top: 2px;"></div>
<div style="float: left;margin-left: 10px;">Work</div>
<div style="clear: both"></div>

<div style="height: 10px; width: 10px; background-color: #3366CC; float: left;margin-top: 2px;"></div>
<div style="float: left;margin-left: 10px;">Work + Study</div>
<div style="clear: both"></div>

<div style="height: 10px; width: 10px; background-color: #FF9900; float: left;margin-top: 2px;"></div>
<div style="float: left;margin-left: 10px;">Study</div>
<div style="clear: both"></div>

<div style="height: 10px; width: 10px; background-color: #109618; float: left;margin-top: 2px;"></div>
<div style="float: left;margin-left: 10px;">Other *</div>
<div style="clear: both"></div>

</div>
<div style='clear:both'></div>


</div>
<div style='width:100%; overflow:hidden;'>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">BA Programmes</h1>
<ul class="disc">
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://moodle.ucl.ac.uk/course/view.php?id=26809" target="_self">BA Handbook</a>: This guide in Moodle contains all the essential information for students on Philosophy undergraduate degrees including combined honours.
</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/docs/ug-progress-form.doc" target="_self">Undergraduate Student Progress Form (Word)</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students" target="_self">Forms and Information</a> for all UCL Philosophy students.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/ba-programmes/ba-modules" target="_self">BA Modules 2017/18</a>: List of modules running.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/ba-programmes/key-contacts" target="_self">Key Contacts:</a> Who to get in touch with for various undergraduate enquiries.</li>
<li>BA Philosophy Timetable (N.B. shows both terms together).<br />- <a href="https://timetable.ucl.ac.uk/tt/deptTimet.do?firstReq=Y&amp;deptId=PHIL*&amp;deptYear=1" target="_self">BA Level 1</a><br />- <a href="https://timetable.ucl.ac.uk/tt/deptTimet.do?firstReq=Y&amp;deptId=PHIL*&amp;deptYear=2" target="_self">BA Level 2</a><br />- <a href="https://timetable.ucl.ac.uk/tt/deptTimet.do?firstReq=Y&amp;deptId=PHIL*&amp;deptYear=3" target="_self">BA Level 3</a></li>
<li><p class="p"><strong>Undergraduate
Prizes</strong>:
 The department awards the following prizes to undergraduate
students:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/alumni/richard-murphy-memorial-prize" target="_self"><strong>Richard Murphy Memorial
Prize</strong></a> (£150)
for the best performance in the final year

</li>
<li>AJ Ayer Scholarship Fund (£100) for the best performance in the
second year

</li>
<li>Seasonal Prize, Dawes Hicks Prize (two prizes) and AJ Ayer Prize
(£30 each), for excellent performance in the first and second years.</li>
<li>In addition, we recommend outstanding
students for the faculty medal (Rosa Morrison prize) and for inclusion in the
Dean's List.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/images/indigo/MK_inaug_Long.jpg" width="900" height="350" alt="Professor Kalderon Lecture" class="xl-image" title="Professor Kalderon Lecture" />

<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

        <article class="block block--col-3">
            <h2 class="as-h5">Connect with UCL</h2>
            <ul class="footer__list list-unstyled">
                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/alumni">Alumni</a></li>

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/ba-programmes/ba-courses
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>

  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }

    var js = this.createElement("script");

  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">BA Modules</h1>
<p class="p">Below is the provisional list of modules running in the 2017/18 academic year. Click on the title to see more information including a module description. Module leader email addresses can be found via the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people/permanent-academic-staff">staff pages</a>: </p>






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1010 History of Philosophy I</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Fiona Leigh<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Essay 1 (200 words = 10%) <br />Essay 2 (300 words = 10%) <br />Essay 3 (2000 words = 80%)<br />
Capacity: 105</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p">This course introduces
students to some of the central areas of philosophical enquiry in the Western
philosophical tradition by way of reading classical Greek philosophy. The
course will focus on Plato and then Aristotle, reading works in ethics,
epistemology, metaphysics, psychology and political theory. A sample syllabi,
with the relevant primary texts, is as follows:</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 1: Introduction, Courage, and
universals</em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary
text: Plato, <em>Laches </em></p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 2: What is the virtue of courage?</em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary text: Plato, <em>Laches </em></p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 3: Recollection in Plato</em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary
text: Plato, <em>Meno</em>, 70a-86d</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 4: From belief to knowledge </em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary text: Plato, <em>Meno</em> (the rest), 86d-100b</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 5: Plato’s Forms and
‘Heracliteanism’ </em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary texts: Plato, <em>Phaedo</em> 74a-75b; 100a-e, <em>Republic</em> 476a-480a</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 6: Plato on Love and Desire </em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary
texts: Plato, <em>Symposium</em> 201d-212c, <em>Phaedrus</em> 247a-248e;
252d-256e, <em>Lysis</em> 218d-222a</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 7: Aristotle’s Metaphysics -
Hylomorphism </em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary text: Aristotle, <em>Metaphysics</em>, VII.1-4; <em>Physics</em>, II.1-3 </p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 8: Ethics and the function argument
</em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary text: Aristotle, <em>Nicomachean Ethics</em>, book I (all of book
I)</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 9: The rational and irrational
parts of the soul</em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary
text: Aristotle, <em>Nicomachean Ethics </em>I.13,
<em>de Anima</em> I.1, III.1-3</p>
<p class="p"><em>Week 10: Slavery</em></p>
<p class="p">            Primary text: Aristotle, <em>Politics</em>
I.1-6 &amp; I.13</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1011 History of Philosophy II</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Rory Madden<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Exam 2h<br />
Capacity: 165<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br />
PHIL1011 is an introduction to Early Modern
(17th and 18th Century) philosophy, concentrating on two celebrated but
contrasting philosophers of this period: René Descartes (1596 - 1650) the first
of the great Continental Rationalists, and David Hume (1711 - 1776) the last of
the great British Empiricists. In the first half of term we will be thinking
through Descartes' Meditations (1641), and in the second half of term Book 1 of
Hume's Treatise of Human Nature (1739-40), the respective masterpieces of these
two philosophers.  Each week’s lecture
and class concerns the author’s treatment of some aspect of metaphysics, mind,
and knowledge.</p>
<p class="p">Provisional Syllabus:</p>
<p class="p">Weeks 1-5: Descartes</p>
<p class="p">•             Introduction and Doubt</p>
<p class="p">•             Cogito</p>
<p class="p">•             God and Clear &amp; Distinct Ideas</p>
<p class="p">•             God and Clear &amp; Distinct Ideas continued</p>
<p class="p">•             Mind &amp; Body</p>
<p class="p">Weeks 6-10: Hume</p>
<p class="p">•             Introduction</p>
<p class="p">•             Ideas and Impressions</p>
<p class="p">•             Causation</p>
<p class="p">•             External Objects</p>
<p class="p">•             Personal Identity</p>
<p class="p">Example exam questions:</p>
<p class="p">•             How, if at all, can the meditator be certain of her own
existence?</p>
<p class="p">•             Is Descartes’ argument for a real distinction between
mind and body a sound argument?</p>
<p class="p">•             Explain and assess Hume’s views about our belief in
external objects.</p>
<p class="p">•             Does Hume show that causation is all in the mind?
</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1012 Knowledge and Reality</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Amia Srinivasan<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Weekly reading responses (15%) <br />Essay 1 (1000 words = 35%) <br />Essay 2 (2000 words = 50%)<br />
Capacity: 135</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p">The course provides an introduction to epistemology and metaphysics. Topics to be discussed include: the nature of knowledge, scepticism, whether theism is rational, why the universe exists, free will, personal identity, and the metaphysics of race.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1013 Introduction to Logic 2</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ethan Nowak<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: 40% Coursework; 60% Exam (2 hour exam in Term 3)<br />
Capacity: 75<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br />
This module aims to introduce the student to the
main ideas, concepts and  techniques of
contemporary first-order logic, including syntax, semantics and natural
deduction.</p>
<p class="p">NB PHIL1014 is a
pre-requisite for this module.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1014 Introduction to Logic 1</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ethan Nowak<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: 40% Coursework; 60% Exam (at end of Term 1)<br />
Capacity: 85<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br />This module aims to introduce the student to the main ideas, concepts and techniques of contemporary propositional logic, including syntax, semantics and natural deduction.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1015 Introduction to Moral Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Mark Kalderon<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Exam 2hr<br />
Capacity: 165</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p"> Introduction to central themes in moral
philosophy through the examination of key historical texts.</p>
<p class="p">Required reading:</p>
<p class="p">· David Hume, A Treatise of
Human Nature (either the Nidditch or the Norton and Norton both OUP)</p>
<p class="p">· Immanuel Kant, Groundwork
of the Metaphysics of Morals, translated by Mary Gregor with an Introduction by
Christine M. Korsgaard, CUP</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading:</p>
<p class="p">· John Rawls, Lecture on the
History of Moral Philosophy</p>
<p class="p">· David Wiggins, Ethics:
Twelve Lectures on the Philosophy of Morality</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Hume’s Moral Science</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: David
Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature, Introduction, 1.1.1-5</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Introduction; Wiggins, chapter 1</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. The Combat of Reason
and the Passions</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: David
Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature, 2.3.3, 3.1.1-2</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Hume I, Hume II; Wiggins, chapter 2</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. Moral Rationalism and
Moral Sentimentalism</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: David
Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature, 3.1.1-2</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Hume IV; Wiggins, chapter 3</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Justice Not a Natural
Virtue</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: David Hume,
A Treatise of Human Nature, 3.2.1</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Hume III; Wiggins, chapter 3</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Justice as an
Artificial Virtue</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: David
Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature, 3.2.2</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Hume III; Wiggins, chapter 4</p>
<p class="p">Week 6. The Project of Kant’s
Groundwork</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: Immanuel
Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals, Preface, Section 1</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Christine
Korsgaard’s Introduction to Mary Gregor’s Translation (CUP); Rawls, Kant I</p>
<p class="p">Week 7. The Derivation of the
First Formula</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: Immanuel
Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals, Section 1</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Kant II; Wiggins, chapter 5</p>
<p class="p">Week 8. Applying the First
Formula</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: Immanuel
Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals, Section 2</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Kant II; Wiggins, chapter 5</p>
<p class="p">Week 9. Derivation of the
Second Formula</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: Immanuel
Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals, Section 2</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Kant III; Wiggins, chapter 5</p>
<p class="p">Week 10. Derivation of the
Third Formula</p>
<p class="p">· Required reading: Immanuel
Kant, Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals, Section 2</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Rawls,
Kant IV; Wiggins, chapter 5</p>
<p class="p">Sample questions:</p>
<p class="p">The essay titles are divided
into three sections. One section is one Hume, one on Kant, one on Hume and
Kant. The last, comparative questions are the most difficult.</p>
<p class="p">Section A Hume</p>
<p class="p">1. What are the differences
between the natural and artificial virtues?</p>
<p class="p">2. 'It may not be contrary to
reason, as Hume understands it, to prefer the destruction of the entire world
to the scratching of one's finger, but it is a mad, insane preference.'
Discuss.</p>
<p class="p">3. Does the merit of an
action derive from a virtuous motive as Hume contends?</p>
<p class="p">Section B Kant</p>
<p class="p">4. Schiller writes 'I like to
serve my friends, but unfortunately I do so by inclination. And so I am
bothered by the thought that I am not virtuous. There is no other way but this!
You must seek to despise them. And do with repugnance what duty bids you.'
Discuss.</p>
<p class="p">5. How might a maxim's
passing the universalizability test fail to be necessary for its being morally
permissible?</p>
<p class="p">6. 'While emotionally
resonant, the Formula of Humanity is impossible to apply in the sense that no
specific duty can be derived from it in any given circumstance.' Discuss.</p>
<p class="p">Section C Hume vs Kant</p>
<p class="p">7. Can categorical duties be
accomodated within a the framework of Humean sentimentalism?</p>
<p class="p">8. Is moral judgment
determined by reason or sentiment?</p>
<p class="p">9. 'There is no place for the
passions in Kant's ethics.' Discuss. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1016 Introduction to Political Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Benedict Rumbold<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 2000 words<br />
Capacity: 180<br />
</p>
<p class="p">Description: In this course, we investigate
three large sets of questions about justice and the importance of liberty and
equality for a just society:</p>
<p class="p">(1) Liberty: What is liberty
and why is it important? Which liberties, if any, should a just society
protect? Freedom of expression? Freedom from interference? Economic Liberty?
Sexual liberty? Political liberty? Can these different liberties come into
conflict, and if so, should some have priority over others?</p>
<p class="p">(2) Equality: What is
equality, is it important, and which kinds of equality, if any, should a just
society ensure? Equality of opportunity? Equality of income and wealth?
Political equality? </p>
<p class="p">(3) Reconciliation: Can a
society ensure the equality and liberty of its citizens at the same time, or
are these political values inherently in conflict with one another? If they are
conflicting values, which is to take priority?</p>
<p class="p">To facilitate our
investigation, we will examine three theories of justice: utilitarianism,
libertarianism, and liberal egalitarianism.</p>
<p class="p">Examples of reading
materials:</p>
<p class="p">1. Introduction</p>
<p class="p">Martin King: Letter from
Brimingham Jail</p>
<p class="p">2. Utilitarianism 1</p>
<p class="p">Jeremy Bentham - The
Principles of Morals and Legislation (selections)</p>
<p class="p">Jeremy Bentham - Principles
of the Civil Code, Of Slavery</p>
<p class="p">Frederick Douglass – What the
Black Man Wants</p>
<p class="p">3. Utilitarianism 2</p>
<p class="p">John Stuart Mill – Utilitarianism</p>
<p class="p">Peter Singer – Famine,
Affluence, and Morality</p>
<p class="p">4. Utilitarianism 3</p>
<p class="p">John Stuart Mill - On Liberty
(selections)</p>
<p class="p">US Supreme Court – Carhart v.
Gonzales</p>
<p class="p">5. Libertarianism 1</p>
<p class="p">Robert Nozick - Anarchy,
State, Utopia (selections)</p>
<p class="p">6. Libertarianism 2</p>
<p class="p">Robert Nozick - Anarchy,
State, Utopia (selections)</p>
<p class="p">Debra Satz - Voluntary
Slavery and the Limits of Markets, Law and Ethics of</p>
<p class="p">Human Rights, Vol. 1, Issue
3, pp. 86-109</p>
<p class="p">7. Public Goods</p>
<p class="p">Milton Friedman - Capitalism
and Freedom (selections)</p>
<p class="p">Mancus Olson – The Logic of
Collective Action</p>
<p class="p">8. Liberal Egalitarianism 1</p>
<p class="p">John Rawls - A Theory of
Justice, Revised Edition (selections)</p>
<p class="p">9. Liberal Egalitarianism 2</p>
<p class="p">John Rawls - A Theory of
Justice, Revised Edition (selections)</p>
<p class="p">10. Equality of Opportunity
and School Choice</p>
<p class="p">Adam Swift – How not to be a
hypocrite</p>
<p class="p">Elizabeth Anderson –
Rethinking equality of opportunity </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL1017 Philosophical Study
Skills: Reading, Understanding, and Essay Writing</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Various - Convenor Sarah Richmond<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: n/a<br />
Assessment: Essay 2000 words<br />
Capacity: 65</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p">Each tutorial group is allocated to a tutor, usually an advanced
PhD student, who meets weekly for an hour to discuss set texts; to improve the
students’ understanding of them; to debate; and to instruct the students in
essay-writing skills. Each student in the group will write two essays in the
course of the term, to be presented to the group.</p>
<p class="p">The tutor is responsible for
deciding – according to their expertise - the selection of texts to be studied, although this is done in
consultation with the course convenor. See below for examples. In general, there will be a spread of different
philosophical texts, possibly on a common theme, and frequently including both
‘historical’ and more contemporary texts.</p>
<p class="p">Assessment method </p>
<p class="p">2,000-word submitted essay,
due in on the first day of the following Term. It is possible to work up and
submit one of the essays presented earlier in the term, in the light of
feedback from the tutor.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading</p>
<p class="p">There is no recommended
background reading in advance of the course beginning. Any knowledge of
philosophy already secured is likely to be useful.</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">As mentioned above, nothing
is fixed in advance and the ‘syllabus’ is settled by the course tutor. Below
are samples of readings that have been set, from different domains of philosophy.</p>
<p class="p">Political Philosophy</p>
<p class="p">Isaiah Berlin (1969) ‘Two
Concepts of Liberty’ esp. sections 1,2 and 5, printed in Berlin Liberty (2002,
Oxford University Press) </p>
<p class="p">Gerald C. MacCallum, Jr.
(1967) ‘Negative and Positive Freedom’ Philosophical Review 76: 312-34 </p>
<p class="p">Quentin Skinner (2002) ‘A
Third Concept of Liberty’ Proceedings of the British Academy 117: 237-68 </p>
<p class="p">G. A. Cohen (2001) ‘Freedom
and Money’ Revista Argentina de Teoria Juridica 2: 1-32; printed in G. A. Cohen
(ed. Michael Otsuka) On the Currency of Egalitarian Justice and Other Essays in
Political Philosophy (2011, Princeton University Press)</p>
<p class="p">Metaphysics</p>
<p class="p">David Lewis: ‘The paradoxes
of Time Travel’.</p>
<p class="p">David Lewis: Selection from
On the Plurality of Worlds. §1.1: The thesis of plurality of worlds, pp. 1-3;
§1.3: Closeness, pp. 20-27.</p>
<p class="p">Saul Kripke: Naming and
Necessity, selection from lecture 1, pp. 41-53. </p>
<p class="p">Ancient Philosophy</p>
<p class="p">Plato, The Apology and Plato,
Crito</p>
<p class="p">Sample questions</p>
<p class="p">Here are some titles from
recent submitted essays:</p>
<p class="p">Why do egalitarians need to
balance the value of fairness against other values, such as respect?</p>
<p class="p">Explain and assess Hare’s
defence against the claim that ‘Utilitarianism must be an objectionable
doctrine, if it can condone or even comment slavery’.</p>
<p class="p">How does Lewis try to escape the
paradoxical consequences that could seem to arise for Tim if he succeeds in his
aim of travelling backwards in time to kill his grandfather? </p>
<p class="p">‘The winner’ and ‘the loser’
might not designate the same man (Nixon) in all possible worlds, Kripke claims.
How does he justify his idea that a name like ‘Nixon’ is different from these
descriptions in that they do designate the same individual in all possible
worlds?</p>
<p class="p">Is the internalist view of
justification correct? </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2030 Aesthetics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: James Wilson<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 2500 words<br />
Capacity: 90<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This module provides an introduction to some key topics issues in aesthetics and the philosophy of art. Topics to be examined include the nature and justifiability of aesthetic judgments (how can there be a 'standard of taste'?), the aesthetic appreciation of nature, theories of the nature and value of art (can just anything count as art if you put it in a gallery?) and the ontology of artistic works. <a href="http://readinglists.ucl.ac.uk/modules/phil2030.html" target="_blank">http://readinglists.ucl.ac.uk/modules/phil2030.html </a></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2031 Morality and Literature</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Sarah Richmond<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 2500 words<br />
Capacity: 60<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> The aim of this course is to examine the
relationship between morality and literature from a number of angles. Some
topics will be more historical, while others will be more thematic. Historical authors whose ideas are discussed
may include: Plato; Lessing; Rousseau; Schiller and Sartre. Questions and
problems to be discussed may include: is a literary work subject to moral
evaluation? If so, how? How might its moral evaluation contribute to its
overall evaluation as a literary artwork? Is literary censorship ever morally
justified? Can literary works be regarded as morally instructive?</p>
<p class="p">This course is suitable for
students interested in both philosophy and literature, and who enjoy reading.
Reading will include both literary and philosophical works.</p>
<p class="p">Assessment method: Essay of 2,500 words. There will be an
opportunity to write a formative essay.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading</p>
<p class="p">There are a number of recent
edited collections, which contain essays that will give students an idea of
contemporary academic discussion:</p>
<p class="p">(Ed) Jerrold Levinson (1998),
Aesthetics and Ethics: Essays at the Intersection, (Cambridge; CUP)</p>
<p class="p">(Eds) A. Neill and A. Ridley
(2008), Arguing about Art, (3rd Edition)
(London: Routledge)</p>
<p class="p">(Eds) J.L. Bermudez and
Sebastian Gardner (2003), Art and Morality (London: Routledge)</p>
<p class="p">See also Myles Burnyeat's
1997 Tanner Lectures (Culture and Society). </p>
<p class="p">For historical texts, the
following will give students an idea of important contributions to this area:</p>
<p class="p">Plato’s discussion of poetry
in The Republic Book X</p>
<p class="p">G.E. Lessing, Laocoon and
Pieces 75,76,77 from the Hamburg Dramaturgy</p>
<p class="p">Kant, Critique of Judgment §§
40-42 and 49</p>
<p class="p">Friedrich Schiller, Letters
on the Aesthetic Education of Mankind (esp. Letters X and XXVII)</p>
<p class="p">Oscar Wilde, ‘Preface’ to
Portrait of Dorian Gray; 'The Soul of
Man under Socialism'; 'The Critic as Artist’.</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Here are some sample topics
and associated reading suggestions:</p>
<p class="p">Plato's Republic. The
'quarrel between philosophy and poetry'</p>
<p class="p">Plato, Republic, Book X; 595a-608c 
</p>
<p class="p">Janaway, Christopher, (2005),
‘Plato’, in (Eds) Berys Gaut and Dominic M Lopes, The Routledge Companion to
Aesthetics (2nd ed), (London: Routledge), pp. 3-14</p>
<p class="p">Janaway, Christopher, (1995),
Images of Excellence (Oxford: Clarendon Press), ch 6</p>
<p class="p">Moss, Jessica (2007) ‘What is
Imitative Poetry and Why is it Bad?’, in (Ed) G.R.F.Ferrari, The Cambridge
Companion to Plato’s Republic, (Cambridge: CUP): 415-444</p>
<p class="p">Nehamas, Alexander (1988),
'Plato and the Mass Media,' Monist 77: 214-34</p>
<p class="p">Pappas, N, (2008), ‘Plato’s
aesthetics’, entry in the online Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy at:
http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/plato-aesthetics/.</p>
<p class="p">Literature as moral
philosophy</p>
<p class="p">Henry James, (1966), The
Golden Bowl, (Harmondsworth: Penguin). (First published 1904).</p>
<p class="p">Martha Nussbaum (1983),
‘Flawed crystals: James’s The Golden Bowl and Literature as Moral Philosophy,
New Literary History, vol 15 (1): 25-50. Reprinted in Nussbaum, Love’s
Knowledge.</p>
<p class="p">Cora Diamond (1983), ‘Having
a Rough Story about What Moral Philosophy Is’, New Literary History , vol 15
(1): 155-169.</p>
<p class="p">Richard Wollheim (1983),
‘Flawed Crystals: James’s The Golden Bowl and the Plausibility of Literature as
Moral Philosophy’, NLH, vol 15 (1): 185-191.</p>
<p class="p">Literature and Censorship</p>
<p class="p">Mary Devereaux (1993), ‘Protected
Space: Politics, Censorship, and the Arts’, Journal of Aesthetics and Art
Criticism, 51:2: 207-15</p>
<p class="p">Richard Shusterman (1984),
‘Aesthetic Censorship: Censoring Art for Art's Sake’, Journal of Aesthetics and
Art Criticism, 43: 2: 171-180</p>
<p class="p">Christopher Butler (1973),
'What Is a Literary Work?', New Literary History, Vol. 5, No. 1: 17-29</p>
<p class="p">Peter McDonald (2004), ‘The
Writer, The Critic, and The Censor. J.M. Coetzee and the Question of
Literature’, Book History, vol 7: 285-301</p>
<p class="p">Jonathan Dollimore (2001),
Sex, Literature and Censorship (Cambridge: Polity)</p>
<p class="p">John Sutherland (1982),
Offensive Literature. Decensorship in Britain, 1960-1982. (London: Junction
Books Ltd)</p>
<p class="p">Sentimentality Michael Tanner
(1976), ‘Sentimentality’, reprinted in (Eds) J. Bermudez and S. Gardner (2003),
Art and Morality, (London: Routledge): 95-110</p>
<p class="p">Anthony Savile,
‘Sentimentality’, in (Eds) A. Neill and A. Ridley (2008), Arguing about Art,
(3rd Edition), (London: Routledge): 315-319</p>
<p class="p">Ira Newman, ‘The Alleged
Unwholesomeness of Sentimentality’, in (Eds) A. Neill and A. Ridley (2008),
Arguing about Art, (3rd Edition), (London: Routledge): 320-332</p>
<p class="p">Mark Jefferson (1983), ‘What
is Wrong with Sentimentality?’, Mind, vol XCII: 519-529</p>
<p class="p">Maria Callas singing 'Un Bel
Di' by Puccini (can be found with youtube link)</p>
<p class="p">Sample questions.</p>
<p class="p">Here are some suggested essay
titles:</p>
<p class="p">Explain and critically
discuss Plato’s claim that poetry appeals to the ‘base part of the soul’.</p>
<p class="p">What, if anything, is wrong
with a work of narrative literature that encourages the reader to identify herself sympathetically with an
immoral character or perspective? Give an example to illustrate your view.</p>
<p class="p">The judgement that something
is ‘sentimental’ is sometimes best
understood in aesthetic terms, but in other contexts the same term can express
moral criticism. Is there some common element in these two uses, or are they
quite unrelated? </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2032 Applied Ethics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: John Vorhaus<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Exam 2h<br />
Capacity: 55<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /></p>
<p class="p">This course will examine some selected topics in applied ethics. </p>
<p class="p">Most, and possibly all, of the following topics will be covered: abortion, euthanasia, non-human animals, the regulation of recreational drugs, affirmative action, world hunger, rape, privacy and ‘designer babies’.</p>
<p class="p">A more general and theoretical lecture will consider the concept of autonomy, as this value is so widely appealed to in this  area. Students will be expected to read at least two papers for most topics, and to participate actively in the back-up seminar. Assessment will be by an two-hour examination, in which students will be expected to answer two questions.  This final paper will offer a wide range of questions to choose from, but a question on each topic is not guaranteed.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2033 Metaphysics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Luke
Fenton-Glynn<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 2500 words<br />
Capacity: 75<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> During this course, we will cover a range of
subjects in metaphysics, including: time, change and identity; necessity and
possibility; and causation and counterfactuals.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general background
reading:</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics (Oxford: OUP)</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Topic 1. Identity Through
Time</p>
<p class="p">• Williams, B. (1979): ‘The Self and the Future’,
Philosophical Review, Vol. 79, pp. 161-180.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics (Oxford:
OUP), Ch. 2</p>
<p class="p">Topic 2. Temporal Parts</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1986): On the Plurality of Worlds (Oxford:
Blackwell), pp. 202-204 &amp; 210.</p>
<p class="p">• Thomson, J. (1983): 'Parthood and Identity Across Time',
Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 80, pp. 201-220.</p>
<p class="p">• Sider, T. (1997): 'Four-Dimensionalism', Philosophical
Review, Vol. 106, pp. 197-231. Sections 1 &amp; 2 (i.e. to p. 213).</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics, Chapter 3</p>
<p class="p">Topic 3. Necessity and
Identity</p>
<p class="p">• Krikpe, S. (1980): Naming and Necessity (Cambridge, MA:
Harvard University Press)</p>
<p class="p">• Putnam, H. (1975): ‘The Meaning of ‘Meaning’’, Minnesota
Studies in the Philosophy of Science, Vol. 7, pp. 131-193.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics, Chapter 5.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 4. Possible Worlds</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1973): Counterfactuals (Oxford: Blackwell),
Ch. 4, Section 1.</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1986): On the Plurality of Worlds, esp. Ch.
1.1</p>
<p class="p">• Stalnaker, R. (1976): ‘Possible Worlds’, Noûs, Vol. 10,
pp. 65-75.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics, Chapter 7</p>
<p class="p">Topic 5. Causes and
Conditions</p>
<p class="p">• Mackie, J. L. (1965): ‘Causes and Conditions’, American
Philosophical Quarterly, Vol. 2, pp. 245-264.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E. J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics, Ch. 9.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 6. Causation and
Counterfactuals</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1986): ‘Causation’ with Postscripts, in his
Philosophical Papers, Vol. 2.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics (Oxford:
OUP), Ch. 10.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 7. Time and Tense</p>
<p class="p">• McTaggart, J. E. (1908): ‘The Unreality of Time’, Mind,
Vol. 17, pp. 457-474.</p>
<p class="p">• Dummett, M. (1960): ‘A Defense of McTaggart’s Proof of
the Unreality of Time’, Philosophical Review, Vol. 69, pp. 497-504.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics (Oxford:
OUP), Ch. 17.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 8: Presentism and
Eternalism</p>
<p class="p">• Sider, T. (2001): Four-Dimensionalism: An Ontology of
Persistence and Time (Oxford: OUP), Ch. 2.</p>
<p class="p">• Markosian, N. (2004): ‘A Defense of Presentism’, Oxford
Studies in Metaphysics, Vol. 1, pp. 47-81.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 9. Space &amp; Time:
Absolutism vs. Relationism</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics, Chapter 14</p>
<p class="p">• Maudlin, T. (2012): Philosophy of Physics: Space and
Time, Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 10. The Direction of
Time</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1976): ‘The Paradoxes of Time Travel’,
American Philosophical Quarterly, Vol. 13, pp. 145-152.</p>
<p class="p">• Sider, T. (2005): ‘Traveling in A- and B-Time’, The
Monist, Vol. 88, pp. 329-335.</p>
<p class="p">• Keller, S. and Nelson, M. (2001): ‘Presentists Should
Believe in Time-Travel’, Australasian Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 79, pp.
333-345.</p>
<p class="p">• Lowe, E.J. (2002): A Survey of Metaphysics, Chapter 18.</p>
<p class="p">Sample questions:</p>
<p class="p">• Is the fact that you remember experiences that some
person had last week sufficient to show that you are that person?</p>
<p class="p">• “The actual world is just one world among others;
non-actual possible worlds are as real as our own.” Discuss.</p>
<p class="p">• Are there necessary truths that are knowable only a
posteriori? Are there contingent truths that can be known a priori?</p>
<p class="p">• What is causation?</p>
<p class="p">• Does only the present exist?</p>
<p class="p">• Is space absolute or relative?</p>
<p class="p">• Is time travel possible </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2034 Philosophy of Mind</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Rory Madden<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 2500 words<br />
Capacity: 60<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This is an intermediate-level module introducing
a range of problems, positions, and arguments in the philosophy of mind, the
philosophical study of mental phenomena and their relation to the rest of
reality. We will cover topics in the
metaphysics of mind before reading week, and topics in the epistemology of mind
after reading week.</p>
<p class="p">Some recommended general
background reading:</p>
<p class="p">• Chalmers, David 2002
Philosophy of Mind: Classical and Contemporary Readings (this anthology
contains many of the core readings below)</p>
<p class="p">• Crane, Tim. 2001
Elements of Mind</p>
<p class="p">• Kim, Jaegwon 1996
Philosophy of Mind</p>
<p class="p">Provisional Syllabus &amp;
Core Readings</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. What is the mind?</p>
<p class="p">• Rorty, Richard 1979
Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature ch 1</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. Mind-brain
identity</p>
<p class="p">• Smart, J.J.C. 1959
‘Sensations and brain processes’ Philosophical Review</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. Functionalism</p>
<p class="p">• Putnam, Hilary 1967 ‘The
Nature of Mental States’ in David Chalmers ed. Readings </p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Mental Causation</p>
<p class="p">• Bennett, Karen 2007
‘Mental Causation’ Philosophical Compass</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Consciousness I</p>
<p class="p">• Nagel, Thomas 1974 ‘What
is it like to be a bat?’ Philosophical Review</p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Consciousness II</p>
<p class="p">• Rosenthal, David 2002
‘Explaining Consciousness’ in Chalmers (ed.) Readings</p>
<p class="p">Week 7. Intentionality</p>
<p class="p">• Dretske, Fred 1994 ‘A
Recipe for Thought’. Reprinted in Chalmers (ed.) Readings</p>
<p class="p">Week 8. Knowledge of One’s
Own Mind</p>
<p class="p">• Armstrong, David 1968 A
Materialist Theory of Mind ch 15. Reprinted as ‘Introspection’ in Cassam (ed.)
1995 Self-Knowledge</p>
<p class="p">Week 9. Knowledge of Other
Minds I</p>
<p class="p">• Ayer, A.J. 1953 ‘One’s
Knowledge of Other Minds’ Theoria</p>
<p class="p">Week 10. Knowledge of
Other Minds II</p>
<p class="p">• Kripke, Saul 1982 Wittgenstein
on Rules and Private Language Postscript ‘Wittgenstein and Other Minds’</p>
<p class="p">Sample Examination
Questions:</p>
<p class="p">• Is intentionality the
mark of the mental?</p>
<p class="p">• Are considerations of
simplicity enough to show that mental states are identical to brain states?</p>
<p class="p">• Is there a naturalistic
recipe for mental representation?</p>
<p class="p">• What, if anything, is
the obstacle to our understanding phenomenal consciousness in physical terms?</p>
<p class="p">• Can higher-order
thoughts explain why some mental states are conscious?</p>
<p class="p">• ‘Our knowledge of other
minds always inferential knowledge’. Is it?</p>
<p class="p">• What are the prospects
for a perceptual model of introspection? </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2035 Knowledge</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Mat Simpson<br />Term: 1 <br />Area: A<br />Assessment: Exam 2h</p>
<p class="p">Description: This module is designed to deal with a variety of topics in epistemology – the philosophical study of knowledge. The curriculum will vary from year to year. Topics include: theories of knowledge; theories of justification or warrant; scepticism; contextualism; sources of knowledge: perception, memory, introspection, testimony.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2045 Philosophy of Language</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ethan Nowak <br /></p>
<p class="p">Term: 1 <br /></p>
<p class="p">Area: A <br /></p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Exam 2h <br /></p>
<p class="p">Capacity: 45<br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: This course will examine some selected topics in the philosophy of  language. Although the precise contents may vary slightly from year to year the course will typically cover: sense and reference, definite descriptions, proper names, metaphor, the distinction between pragmatics and semantics, speech act theory and its application to the legitimacy of pornography. The course is assessed by a sit-down examination in the summer.
</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2047 Ethics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Douglas Lavin<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 2500 words<br />
Capacity: 60<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This module is a survey of central questions and
concepts of recent ethical theory. Precise contents may vary slightly by year.
Some topics include: the nature of the good, egoism, utilitarian accounts of
right and wrong action, virtue (esp. justice and benevolence), partiality and
impartiality, moral luck.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading:</p>
<p class="p">• Williams, Morality an
Introduction to Ethics</p>
<p class="p">• Scheffler,
Consequentialism and Its Critics</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Death</p>
<p class="p">• Nagel, “Death”,
Epicurus, Letter to Menoeceus</p>
<p class="p">• Williams, &quot;The Makropulos
Case: Reflections on the Tedium of Immortality&quot;</p>
<p class="p">Questions: Does death harm
the one who dies? Even if death is a harm in some circumstances, must it always
be? Other things equal, would it be good to be immortal?</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. Well-Being</p>
<p class="p">• Parfit, &quot;What Makes
Someone's Life Go Best?&quot;</p>
<p class="p">• Robert Nozick, &quot;The
Experience Machine”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: What makes a
person’s life go better? Is pleasure the only ultimate source of value? Are a
person's desires the only measure of how well his or her life is going?</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. Egoism</p>
<p class="p">• Williams, “Egoism and
Altruism”</p>
<p class="p">• Butler, “Upon the Love
of Our Neighbour,” Feinberg, “Psychological Egoism,” Raz, “The Amoralist”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: What is
self-interest? Is it the source of all reasons for action? Is it possible to
act for the sake of another’s good or must motivation always bottom out in a
purely selfish element?</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Utilitarianism</p>
<p class="p">• Bentham, Introduction to
the Principles of Morals and Legislation, Ch. I, Mill, Utilitarianism, Chs. I,
II, and V</p>
<p class="p">• Mill, “Remarks on Bentham’s
Philosophy,” Williams and Smart, Utilitarianism for and against</p>
<p class="p">Questions: What is the
utilitarian account of the principles upon which we ought to act? Where does it
locate the philosophical basis of our ideas of right and wrong? What is the
source of attraction of the utilitarian conception of morality?</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Beneficience</p>
<p class="p">• Singer, “Famine,
Affluence and Morality”</p>
<p class="p">• Murphy, “The Demands of
Beneficence,” Miller, “Beneficence, Duty and Distance”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: How much, if at
all, must we help others?</p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Beneficience</p>
<p class="p">• Taurek, “Should the
Numbers Count?”</p>
<p class="p">• Parfit, “Innumerate
Ethics,” Kamm, “Equal Treatment and Equal Chances,” Anscombe,</p>
<p class="p">“Who is Wronged?”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: Do the numbers
count morally speaking? Is the fact that one group has more people require us
to aid its members in preference to another, smaller group?</p>
<p class="p">Week 7. Justice</p>
<p class="p">• Foot, “The Problem of
Abortion and the Doctrine of Double Effect”</p>
<p class="p">• Feinberg, “The Nature
and Value of Rights,” Anscombe, “Mr Truman’s Degree,”</p>
<p class="p">Thomson, “The Trolley
Problem”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: Is it harder to
justify actively harming someone, intentionally or not, than it is to justify
merely allowing someone to be harmed? Is it harder to justify intentionally
harming someone, than it it is to justify merely knowingly harming someone?</p>
<p class="p">Week 8. Justice</p>
<p class="p">• Foot, “Utilitarianism
and the Virtues,” Nozick, Anarchy, State and Utopia, ch. 3</p>
<p class="p">• Geach, “Good and Evil,”
Scheffler, “Agent-Centered Restrictions, Rationality and the Virtues”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: Foot says that
the deep pull of utilitariaism comes from the thought that it can’t be right to
‘prefer the worse to the better.’ How does she argue that the attractiveness of
the thought is only an illusion? How can it be rational to abide by a
constraint on action even when flouting it would prevent more extensive
violations of that very constraint? How can it be wrong to, say, lie even when
doing so will prevent more and worse lies from being told?</p>
<p class="p">Week 9. Love and Morality</p>
<p class="p">• Wolf, “Moral Saints”</p>
<p class="p">• Wolf, “Morality and
Partiality,” Williams, “Persons, Character, Morality”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: If love and
friendship are not part of impartial morality, how are we to reconcile their
potentially conflicting demands? A moral saint is someone “whose every action
is as morally good as possible, a person, that is, who is as morally worthy as
can be.” Why does Wolf think that a moral saint is not a good kind of person to
be or a good kind of life tolead? Is she correct?</p>
<p class="p">Week 10. Moral Luck</p>
<p class="p">• Nagel, “Moral Luck”</p>
<p class="p">• Williams, “Moral Luck”</p>
<p class="p">Questions: For there to be
moral luck is for one’s moral status to depend on facts outside one’s control.
Can there be moral luck? Is it legitimate for luck to play a role in how blame
and praise are distirbuted? </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2048 Intermediate Logic</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: José Zalabardo<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Exam 2h + Home Work exercises<br />
Capacity: 30<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> The purpose of this course is to present the
basic methods and results of contemporary logic. The emphasis is on the
practical skill of formulating and proving results about logical systems.</p>
<p class="p">The textbook for this
course is J. Zalabardo, Introduction to the Theory of Logic, Westview, 2000. We
should be able to cover Chapters 1-3 and some of Chapter 7. The module is
assessed by homework (40%) and an exam in the spring (60%). There will be two
batches of assessed homework, one due after reading week and the other after
Easter. You are expected to read the relevant passages of the book before the
lecture, and to attempt the exercises in the book.</p>
<p class="p">The module presupposes familiarity with systems of propositional and first-order logic, at the level of modules PHIL1014 and PHIL1013.</p>
<p class="p">Topics to be covered
include:</p>
<p class="p">1. Sets</p>
<p class="p">2. Mathematical proof</p>
<p class="p">3. Relations</p>
<p class="p">4. Functions</p>
<p class="p">5. Inductive definitions
and inductive proofs</p>
<p class="p">6. Propositional syntax
and semantics</p>
<p class="p">7. First-order syntax and
semantics</p>
<p class="p">8. Models </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2051 Topics in Political Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Joe Horton<br />Term: 1 
<br />Area: B<br />Assessment: Essay (2,500 words) <br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: This module is designed to deal with a variety of topics in political philosophy. It is intended for students with a range of specializations, but some background knowledge in political philosophy.</p>
<p class="p">Curriculum varies by year: topics include international justice; distributive justice; democracy; the social contract.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2053 Topics in Aristotle</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Simona
Aimar<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: 1st essay (1500 words 35%) 2nd essay (2200 words 65%)<br />
Capacity: 30<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">
Description: <br /></p>
<p class="p">This course offers an advanced introduction to central parts of Aristotle’s work. We will have a problem-based approach, and try to assess how Aristotle addresses his own philosophical questions. In particular, we’ll focus on connections between his Metaphysics and Physics, and also look at how these connections have implications on other branches of Aristotle’s philosophical system. Here is the current list of topics: </p>
<p class="p">1. Substances and their properties</p>
<p class="p">2. Change, Matter and Form</p>
<p class="p">3. The Four Causes</p>
<p class="p">4. Knowledge</p>
<p class="p">5. Perception</p>
<p class="p">6. Place</p>
<p class="p">7. Time</p>
<p class="p">8. Soul</p>
<p class="p">9. Women and God</p>
<p class="p">Students are expected to actively participate in class.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2054 Matters of Life and Death</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Ulrike Heuer</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 2500 words</p>
<p class="p">Capacity: TBC</p>
<p class="p">Description: This module will be address questions regarding the metaphysical and ethical significance of death, dying, and survival. Precise content may vary slightly by year. Topics include: personal survial, the badness of death, immortality, the value of life, the moral difference of killing and letting die, euthanasia, the death and killing of non-human animals.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL2055 Truth, Facts and Properties</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Mat Simpson<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: A
<br />Assessment: Exam 2hrs<br />Capacity:25</p>
<p class="p"> Description: In this module we will discuss popular theories of truth, and then examine the various ontological views – theories about what exists – which philosophers have thought to be motivated by considerations about truth. We will discuss popular theories of facts and properties, including realism about universals, trope theory, and nominalism. We will also ask whether such ontological theories are rightly motivated by considerations about truth. Text include:</p>
<p class="p">• Kirkham, R. Theories of Truth, MIT Press 1992</p>
<p class="p">• D.M. Armstrong Truth and Truthmakers, Cambridge University Press 2004</p>
<p class="p">• Helen Beebee and Julian Dodd, eds., Truthmakers: The Contemporary Debate, Oxford University Press 2005</p>
<p class="p">• Alex Oliver and D.H. Mellor, eds. Properties, Oxford University Press 1997</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3031 Global Justice and Health</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: James Wilson<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 60<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This module explores ethical questions in global health by connecting the literature in global health with recent writings in moral and political philosophy. The first half raises some more general issues about global inequalities in health and their causes, and then explores some central issues in moral and political philosophy, including the normative significance of nations, and human rights approaches to health. The second half looks at some more specific issues where philosophers have contributed to debates in global health, including the ethics of research in developing countries and access to pharmaceuticals. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3039 Early Wittgenstein</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: José
Zalabardo<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Exam 2h<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> The purpose of this course is to present some of
the central doctrines of Wittgenstein’s Tractatus-: the Tractarian Account of
Representation and Reality (TARR). We can characterise TARR as involving three
main components.</p>
<p class="p">The first component of
TARR is the view that everyday propositions don’t represent the world directly:
they represent the world through the mediation of a class of postulated
propositions, known as elementary propositions (Elementarsätze). Everyday
propositions represent the world by being truth functions of elementary propositions.</p>
<p class="p">The second component of
TARR is an account of the nature of elementary propositions and of how they
represent the world. On this account, an elementary proposition is a
combination of items known as names. Names are referential expressions. An elementary
proposition represents the referents of its names as combined with one another
in the same way in which the names are combined in the proposition. The
proposition is true if the referents are so combined; false if they are not.
The referents of names are simple items known as objects. The combinations of
objects that elementary propositions represent as obtaining are known as states
of affairs (Sachverhalte).</p>
<p class="p">The third component of
TARR is an account of the structure of reality, according to which a possible
state of the world is constituted by the states of affairs that obtain in it.
Two states of the world differ from one another only if there are states of
affairs that obtain in one and not in the other. And for every set of states of
affairs there is a possible state of the world in which the states of affairs
that obtain are precisely the elements of the set.</p>
<p class="p">Thus, according to TARR,
elementary propositions and states of affairs provide the interface between
language and the world. Propositions represent the world by their
truth-functional dependence on elementary propositions. These, in turn,
represent states of affairs. This enables propositions to represent the whole
of reality, since everything that is the case, and everything that can be the
case, consists in the obtaining and non-obtaining of states of affairs—what
truth functions of elementary propositions represent.</p>
<p class="p">Taken as an intuitive
model, TARR is fairly easy to understand—we can form a conception of what
things would have to be like in order for TARR to be correct. A precise,
literal understanding of the view is much harder to achieve. And it is even
harder to grasp why anyone would think that this is how things are in
actuality—that language and reality have the structure that TARR attributes to
them and that the former represents the latter as TARR says it does.
Specifically, it is hard to understand why Wittgenstein thought this.
Addressing these questions is the main goal of this course.</p>
<p class="p">The lectures will be based
on a book I’m writing on the topic: Representation and Reality in
Wittgenstein’s Tractatus. It’s available to students on Moodle. Please do not
circulate without permission.</p>
<p class="p">TOPICS</p>
<p class="p">1. Russell’s dual-relation
theory of judgment</p>
<p class="p">2. Russell’s
multiple-relation theory of judgment</p>
<p class="p">3. Russell and
Wittgenstein on forms</p>
<p class="p">4. Wittgenstein’s picture
theory</p>
<p class="p">5. Frege on unity and
unsaturatedness</p>
<p class="p">6. Wittgenstein on the
unity of the proposition</p>
<p class="p">7. Wittgenstein on the
unity of facts</p>
<p class="p">8. Objects and expressions
as common structural features</p>
<p class="p">9. Substance and
simplicity</p>
<p class="p">READINGS</p>
<p class="p">Primary sources</p>
<p class="p">Wittgenstein</p>
<p class="p">There are two main English
translations of the Tractatus, one by by C. K. Ogden (London: Routledge and
Kegan Paul, 1922), and one by David Pears and Brian McGuinness (London:
Routledge and Kegan Paul, 2nd ed.1974). I tend to use the Pears and McGuinness,
but although they differ in important respects, either would be fine.</p>
<p class="p">I have prepared a
hypertext version of the Pears and McGuinness translation. It doesn't work on
some browsers.</p>
<p class="p">If you know any German,
there is a very useful edition by Joachim Schulte and Brian McGuinness
(Frankfurt am Main: Suhrkamp, 1989), collating sections of the Tractatus with
relevant passages from preliminary manuscripts.</p>
<p class="p">Another important primary
source is Wittgenstein's Notebooks, 1914-1916 (Oxford: Blackwell, 2nd ed.1979).
This volume contains the main extant manuscripts from the period when
Wittgenstein was working on the Tractatus.</p>
<p class="p">Frege and Russell</p>
<p class="p">We will be paying close
attention to the origin of Wittgenstein's ideas in the work of Russell and
Frege. We will be looking mainly at the following texts:</p>
<p class="p">For Frege, &quot;Function
and Concept&quot; and &quot;On Concept and Object&quot;, both translated in
Translations from the Philosophical Writings of Gottlob Frege, edited by Max
Black and P. T. Geach, Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1980.</p>
<p class="p">And for Russell:</p>
<p class="p">Chapter 4 of The
Principles of Mathematics. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1903.</p>
<p class="p">&quot;On the Nature of
Truth and Falsehood.&quot; In Philosophical Essays, 147-59. London: Longmans,
Green, 1910.</p>
<p class="p">Chapter 12 of The Problems
of Philosophy . London: Williams &amp; Norgate, 1912.</p>
<p class="p">&quot;Theory of Knowledge:
The 1913 Manuscript.&quot; In The Collected Papers of Bertrand Russell. Vol 7,
edited by Elizabeth Ramsden Eames and Kenneth Blackwell. London: Allen &amp;
Unwin, 1984. (Part I, Chapters VII and IX, and Part II, Chapters I and V)</p>
<p class="p">The fourth lecture of The
Philosophy of Logical Atomism. LaSalle, Ill.: Open Court, 1985.</p>
<p class="p">Secondary sources</p>
<p class="p">Books</p>
<p class="p">There are many book-length
expositions and commentaries of the Tractatus. Many of them make some good
points but they all differ in important respects from the interpretation that
I'll be presenting. The following might be particularly useful:</p>
<p class="p">Max Black. A Companion to
Wittgenstein's Tractatus. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1964.</p>
<p class="p">James Griffin.
Wittgenstein's Logical Atomism. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1964.</p>
<p class="p">David Pears. The False
Prison: A Study of the Development of Wittgenstein's Philosophy. Volume I.
Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1987.</p>
<p class="p">Articles and book chapters</p>
<p class="p">I will recommend readings
on particular topics in the lectures, but here is an unsystematic selection of
interesting articles on the issues that we will be discussing:</p>
<p class="p">Candlish, Stewart.
&quot;The Unity of the Proposition and Russell's Theories of Judgment.&quot; In
Bertrand Russell and the Origins of Analytical Philosophy, edited by Ray Monk
and Anthony Palmer, 103-35. Bristol: Thoemmes Press, 1996.</p>
<p class="p">Conant, James.
&quot;Elucidation and Nonsense in Frege and Early Wittgenstein.&quot; In The
New Wittgenstein, edited by Alice Crary and Rupert Read, 174-217. London:
Routledge, 2000.</p>
<p class="p">----. &quot;The Search for
Logically Alien Thought: Descartes, Kant, Frege, and the Tractatus.&quot;
Philosophical Topics 20 (1992): 115-80.</p>
<p class="p">---. &quot;Two Conceptions
of Die Überwindung der Metaphysik. Carnap and Early Wittgenstein.&quot; In
Wittgenstein in America, edited by Timothy McCarthy and Sean C. Stidd, 13-61.
Oxford: Clarendon, 2001.</p>
<p class="p">Geach, Peter T.
&quot;Saying and Showing in Frege and Wittgenstein.&quot; Acta Philosophica
Fennica 28 (1976): 54-70.</p>
<p class="p">Griffin, Nicholas.
&quot;Russell's Multiple Relation Theory of Judgement.&quot; Philosophical
Studies 47 (1985): 213-48.</p>
<p class="p">---. &quot;Wittgenstein's
Criticism of Russell's Theory of Judgment.&quot; Russell 5 (1986): 132-45.</p>
<p class="p">Hylton, Peter. &quot;The
Nature of the Proposition and the Revolt against Idealism.&quot; In Philosophy
in History, edited by Richard Rorty, J. B. Schneewind and Quentin Skinner,
375-97. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1984.</p>
<p class="p">---. Russell, Idealism,
and the Emergence of Analytic Philosophy. Oxford: Clarendon, 1990.</p>
<p class="p">Ishiguro, Hidé. &quot;Use
and Reference of Names.&quot; In Studies in the Philosophy of Wittgenstein,
edited by Peter Guy Winch, 20-50. London: Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul, 1969.</p>
<p class="p">Kremer, Michael.
&quot;Contextualism and Holism in the Early Wittgenstein: From Prototractatus
to Tractatus .&quot; Philosophical Topics 25 (1997): 87-120.</p>
<p class="p">Linsky, Leonard. &quot;The
Unity of the Proposition.&quot; Journal of the History of Philosophy 30 (1992):
243-73.</p>
<p class="p">Palmer, Anthony. Concept
and Object: The Unity of the Proposition in Logic and Psychology . London:
Routledge, 1988. (Chapter 4)</p>
<p class="p">Pears, David. &quot;The
Relation between Wittgenstein's Picture Theory of Propositions and Russell's
Theory of Judgment.&quot; Philosophical Review 86 (1977): 177-96.</p>
<p class="p">Proops, Ian.
&quot;Wittgenstein on the Substance of the World.&quot; European Journal of
Philosophy 12 (2004): 106-26.</p>
<p class="p">Sluga, Hans. &quot;Frege
against the Booleans.&quot; Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic 28 (1987):
80-98.</p>
<p class="p">Sommerville, Stephen.
&quot;Wittgenstein to Russell (July, 1913). 'I am very sorry to hear ... my
objection paralyses you'.&quot; In Language, Logic, and Philosophy: Proceedings
of the 4th International Wittgenstein Symposium , edited by Rudolf Haller and
Wolfgang Grassl, 182-87. Vienna: Holder-Pichler-Tempsky, 1980. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3040 Adorno: Art and Politics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Tom Stern<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"> Description: <br />The course will provide a detailed overview of
the philosopher T W Adorno’s views on art, politics and the relationship
between the two. We will study certain key primary texts as well as some of the
important secondary literature. <br /></p>
