<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3041 Advanced Topics in Political Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Véronique Munoz-Dardé<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Exam 2h<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /></p>
<p class="p">This advanced course is intended to introduce students to some central questions in political and moral philosophy.</p>
<p class="p">This year’s topic is intimate markets. The course will raise and pursue a number of questions including: Are some markets morally noxious? Should some things not be for sale (for example, surrogacy, sexual services, body parts)? Is there such a thing as self-ownership? How, if at all, does the idea of self-ownership explain, or offer a critique of the notion of intimate markets?</p>
<p class="p">Note that some of the materials in this course overlap with those discussed in last year’s Regulation of Intimacy. For that reason, this course is not open to students who took that course.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3042 Topics in Greek Philosophy: Aristotle</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Fiona Leigh<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /></p>
<p class="p">The course focuses on Aristotle’s
philosophy of mind and moral psychology. After an brief introduction in the
first week to the central tenets of his metaphysics and epistemology, the
course will cover topics including Aristotle's views human nature and human
flourishing, the kinds of cognitive capacities attributable to humans and non-human
animals, the emotions, virtue ethics, the doctrine of the mean and learning to
be good, weakness of the will, and the role of contemplation in the good life.
The central primary texts will be <em>de
Anima</em> and the <em>Nicomachean Ethics</em>,
although other texts will be consulted. A sample syllabi, with the relevant
primary texts, is as follows:</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week 1</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Introduction</strong><em> – overview of life and works, relation
to Plato – and Aristotle’s metaphysics: hylomorphism, substance, the four
causes, body and soul</em></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Metaphysics, VII.1-4, 6, 10-11, 13, 15,
17; Physics II.1-9; III.1-3, VIII.6; de Anima, book 1</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
2</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Eudaimonia</em></strong><strong>
&amp; Function </strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Nicomachean Ethics, book I (especially
chapters 1-5, 7-9, 13)</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
3</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>The Soul &amp; Cognition</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: de Anima, books I-III (especially I.1,
I.4, II.1-6, II.11-12, III.1-3), and de
Motu Animalium, 6-11 </p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
4</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Phantasia</em></strong><strong>
&amp; Emotion</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Rhetoric book II; de Anima, III.3 </p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
5</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Habituation, Pleasure &amp; Cognition</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Nicomachean Ethics, I.13, II.1-3, (II.4-9:
optional), X.9</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
6</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Habituation &amp; Action</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Nicomachean Ethics, II.4 (in detail)</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
7</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>The Doctrine of the Mean</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Nicomachean Ethics, books II-III
(especially II.1-9, III.5-12)</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
8</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>The Mean Relative to Us </strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: (as for last
week:) Nicomachean Ethics, books
II-III (esp. II.1-9, III.5-12), and VI.1-2, 5-6 (optional)</p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week
9</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Virtue and Akrasia
(weakness of the will)</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Nicomachean Ethics, VII.1-10 </p>
<p class="p"><strong><em>Week 10</em></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Two kinds of flourishing?</strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Primary
Text</em>: Nicomachean Ethics, book X (especially
X.6-8)</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3043 Making Sense of the Senses</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">PHIL3043 Making Sense of the Senses<br />
Module Leader: Mark Kalderon<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25</p>
<p class="p">Description: 
An introduction to advanced themes in the
philosophy of perception through a comparison of vision, audition, and touch.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading: </p>
<p class="p">· CD Broad, “Elementary
Reflections on Sense Perception”</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Visuocentrism and
the Metaphysics of Experience</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: CD
Broad, “Elementary Reflections on Sense Perception”, Philosophy, 1952, 27, 100,
3-17; Richard Sorabji, “Aristotle on Demarcating the Five Senses:, The
Philosophical Review, 1971, 80, 1, 55-79</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Matthew
Nudds, “The Significance of the Senses”, Proceedings of the Aristotelian
Society, 2004, 104, 1, 31-51</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. Color Constancy</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading:
Jonathan Cohen, &quot;Color Constancy as Counterfactual&quot;, Australasian
Journal of Philosophy, 2008, 86, 1,
61-92; David Hilbert, &quot;Color Constancy and the Complexity of Color&quot;,
Philosophical Topics, 2005, 33, 1, 141-158</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading:
Dorothea Jameson and Leo M. Hurvich, &quot;Essay Concerning Color
Constancy&quot;, Annual Review of Psychology, 1989, 40, 1-24</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. The Event of
Color?</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Robert
Pasnau, “The Event of Color”, Philosophical Studies, 2009, 142, 3, 353-369</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: CD
Broad, “Elementary Reflections on Sense Perception”, Philosophy, 1952, 27, 100,
3-17</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Color Enactivism</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Alva
Noë, “Colors Enacted”, chapter 4 of Action and Perception, 2004, MIT Press</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: MGF
Martin, &quot;Commentary on Action and Perception&quot; Philosophy and
Phenomenological Research, 2008, 76:3 674--681</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Sounds and Events</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Casey
O'Callaghan, &quot;Sounds and Events&quot; in Sounds and Perception, edited by
Casey O'Callaghan and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP; Robert Pasnau, &quot;What is
Sound&quot; Philosophical Quarterly 50:196 309-24 1999</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Robert
Pasnau, &quot;Sensible Qualities: The Case of Sound&quot; Journal of the
History of Philosophy 38:1 27-40 2000</p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Sound and Space</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading:
Matthew Nudds, “Sound and Space”, Sound and Perception, edited by Cassey
O’Callaghan and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP; Roberto Casati and Jerome Dokic,
“Some Varieties of Spatial Hearing” ”, Sound and Perception, edited by Cassey
O’Callaghan and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Brian
O'Shaughnessy, &quot;The Location of a Perceived Sound&quot; in Sound and
perception, edited by Casey O'Callaghan and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP</p>
<p class="p">Week 7. The Sound of
Silence</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Roy
Sorenson, &quot;Hearing Silence: The Perception and Introspection of
Absences&quot; in Sound and perception, edited by Casey O'Callaghan and Matthew
Nudds, 2009, OUP; Ian Phillips, &quot;Hearing and Hallucinating Silence&quot;
in Hallucinations edited by Fiona MacPherson MIT Press</p>
<p class="p">· Further Reading: Casey
O'Callaghan, &quot;On Privations and Their Perception&quot;, Acata Anal, 2011,
26 175-186; Matt Soteriou, &quot;The Perception of Absence, Space, and
Time&quot; in Perception, Causation, and Objectivity, 2011, OUP</p>
<p class="p">Week 8. The Sense of
Touch?</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Brian
O'Shaughnessy, &quot;The Sense of Touch&quot; Australasian Journal of
Philosophy, 1989; Matthew Ratcliffe, &quot;What is Touch?&quot;, Australasian
Journal of Philosophy, 2011, 1-20</p>
<p class="p">Week 9. Haptic Touch</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading:
Matthew Fulkerson, &quot;The Unity of Haptic Touch&quot;, Philosophical
Psychology, 2011, 24, 4, 493 - 516</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Susan
Lederman and Roberta L. Klatzky, &quot;Hand Movements: A Window into Haptic
Object Recognition&quot; Cognitive Psychology 19 342-68 1987</p>
<p class="p">Week 10. Sight and Touch</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: MGF
Martin, &quot;Sight and Touch&quot; in The Contents of Experience edited by Tim
Crane, 1992, CUP </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3045 Advanced Class in the Philosophy of Mind</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Lucy
O'Brien<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This module is concerned to explore the ways in
which subjects are conscious of themselves. The first six weeks will be
concerned to consider and critically evaluate a number of distinct approaches
to the ways in which we come to know our own psychological lives. The first
three weeks (Section I) will focus on knowledge of belief, and the next three
weeks (Section II) will focus on knowledge of action. In both subsections of
the course a perceptual account of our knowledge of our beliefs and actions
will be contrasted with what we might called practical account of
self-knowledge. An inferential model as an alternative to both will also be
considered. In the last week of Section II (on Libet) students will be
presented with arguments from the neuroscience literature that aim to suggest
that actions are not in fact brought about by the decisions or intentions of
agents - but are automatically produced. The conclusiveness of these arguments
will be evaluated and more recent work in neuroscience suggesting hat Libet’s
original conclusions will be reviewed. The final section of the course (Section
III) will be concerned to explore the nature and significance of a different
kind of consciousness we have of ourselves, that is a consciousness mediated by
the consciousness of other people. Interpersonal self-consciousness is a
consciousness of ourselves as the object of consciousness of another. The
course will consider the nature of such consciousness and will argue that it
should be play an important role in our theory of the self-conscious emotions.
The emotion of shame will be a case study. The course will end by considering
the ways in which human beings can induce and escape such interpersonal
self-consciousness. Reduced Syllabus:</p>
<p class="p">Section I</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Self-Knowledge and
Belief – Introduction and Perceptual Models </p>
<p class="p">Key Readings:</p>
<p class="p">David Armstrong, A Materialist Theory of Mind pp.323-7, 333-8.
Chapter VI, ‘Introspection’ of Self-Knowledge, Cassam (ed).</p>
<p class="p">Sydney Shoemaker, The
Royce Lectures: ‘Self-Knowledge and “Inner Sense”’ (I and II) his First Person
Perspective and Other Essays.</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. Self-Knowledge and
Belief – Transparency Models </p>
<p class="p">Moran, R. Authority and
Estrangement, Chapters 3 and 4. </p>
<p class="p">O’Brien, L. ‘Moran on
Agency and Self-Knowledge’, European Journal of Philosophy, 11: 375-390. </p>
<p class="p">Byrne, A (2011)
‘Transparency and Self-Knowledge - I’ Aristotelian Society, Supplementary
Volume, Vol 85.1</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. Self-Knowledge and
Belief – Inferential Models</p>
<p class="p">Ryle, G. The Concept of Mind, p.160-73, 177-89,
Chapter 1. ‘Self-Knowledge’ of Self-Knowledge, Cassam (ed).</p>
<p class="p">Cassam, Q. (2010-11)
‘Knowing What You Believe’ Aristotelian Society, Proceedings, Vol 111.1</p>
<p class="p">Cassam, Q. Self-Knowledge
for Humans, Chapter 11. </p>
<p class="p">Section II</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Self-knowledge and
Action – Retrospective Models: Observation and Proprioception </p>
<p class="p">O’Brien, L. ‘On Knowing One’s Own Actions’ in Agency and
Self-Awareness (eds) Eilan and Roessler.</p>
<p class="p">Danto, A.C. (1963), ‘What
We Can Do’, Journal of Philosophy LX </p>
<p class="p">Donnellan, K. (1963)
‘Knowing What I am Doing’ Journal of Philosophy LX </p>
<p class="p">O’Shaughnessy, B. (1963),
‘Observation and the Will’, Journal of Philosophy LX</p>
<p class="p">Marcel, A. “The Sense of
Agency: Awareness and Ownership of Action”, in J. Roessler and N. Eilan (eds.)
Agency and Self-Awareness (2003) (Oxford: Oxford University Press), pp. 48-93.</p>
<p class="p">Haggard, P. ‘Conscious
Awareness of Intention and Action’ in J. Roessler and N. Eilan (eds.) Agency
and Self-Awareness (2003) (Oxford: Oxford University Press), pp. 48-93.</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Self-knowledge and
Action – Prospective Models: Intentions and Tryings </p>
<p class="p">Velleman, J.D. Practical Reflection, Princeton, New Jersey:
Princeton University Press</p>
<p class="p">Dunn, R. (1998) ‘Knowing What I’m About To Do Without
Evidence’, International Journal of Philosophical Studies Vo. 6 (2) 231-252</p>
<p class="p">K Setiya (2008) ‘Practical
Knowledge’, Ethics, Vol 118:3, p.. </p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Self-Knowledge and
Action, Inferential Models and Acting on Reason </p>
<p class="p">Paul, S. “How we know what
we’re doing” Philosophers’ Imprint vol. 9, no. 11, October 2009 </p>
<p class="p">Anscombe, G.E.M. Intention</p>
<p class="p">Anscombe, G. E.M. (1963),
‘Two Kinds of Error in Action’, Journal of Philosophy LX </p>
<p class="p">Week 7. Actions without agency? Libet </p>
<p class="p">Libet, Benjamin W. (1999).
Do we have free will? Journal of Consciousness Studies 6:47-57.</p>
<p class="p">Wegner, Daniel M. (2003).
The mind’s best trick: how we experience conscious will. Trends in Cognitive
Sciences, Vol. 7, No. 2, pp. 65-69.</p>
<p class="p">Bayne, T. ‘Libet and the
Case for Free Will Scepticism’ in
Swinburne, Richard, editor(s). Free Will and Modern Science. Oxford: Oxford
University Press, pp. 25-46. . Oxford: Oxford University Press; 2011. p. 25-46.
Link: www.philosophy.ox.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/.../free_will_web.pdf</p>

<p class="p">Week 8: Interpersonal
Self-Consciousness </p>
<p class="p">L. O’Brien, ‘Ordinary
Self-Consciousness’ in Liu and Perry (eds) Consciousness and the Self. </p>
<p class="p">U. Neisser, (1988) ‘Five
kinds of self-knowledge’. Philosophical Psychology, 1, 35–59.(</p>
<p class="p">C. Peacocke,
‘Interpersonal Self-Consciousness’, Philosophical Studies (2014) 170: 25-38</p>

Knowing: Objective self-awareness or consciousness, Developmental Review, 11.3:
231-243.</p>

Roberts, ‘Objectification Theory: Towards Understanding Women’s Lived
Experiences and Mental Health’. Psychology of Women Quarterly, 21.2:173-206</p>
<p class="p">Week 9: Self-Conscious
Emotions: Shame and Embarrassment</p>

of the emotions in man and animals: Chap. X. (Hatred And Anger); Chap. XI
(Disdain—Contempt—Disgust—Guilt—Pride, Etc.—Helplessness—Patience—Affirmation
And Negation.)</p>
<p class="p">M. Lewis, (1995)
‘Embarrassment: The Emotion of Self-Exposure and Self-Evaluation’ in J.P.

Genesis of Shame’ Philosophy and Public Affairs (2001) 30.1: 27-52. </p>
<p class="p">B. Williams, Shame and
Necessity, Chapter IV, ‘Shame and Autonomy’.</p>
<p class="p">Week10:
Self-Consciousness: Inducing and Avoiding</p>
<p class="p">Morgan, D. and O’Brien, L.
(2016) “Getting Out of Your Head: Addiction and the Motive of Self-escape’,
Mind and Language. </p>

self-awareness model of the causes and effects of alcohol consumption.’ </p>

Black Folk, Chapter 1. </p>

and Research. </p>

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3054 Philosophy of Religion</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Rory Madden<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"><br />
Description: <br /> This is an advanced undergraduate/masters level
course covering topics in analytic philosophy of religion. We will be focusing
on three topics</p>
<p class="p">• The philosophy of mind
and epistemology of religious experience</p>
<p class="p">• Some questions of
theological interest related to the metaphysics of persons: disembodiment,
resurrection, and immortality.</p>
<p class="p">• Assessment of theistic
arguments from the apparent fine-tuning for conscious life of the universe.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading:</p>
<p class="p">• James, William 1902 The
Varieties of Religious Experience</p>
<p class="p">• Davies, Brian 1993 An
Introduction to the Philosophy of Religion</p>
<p class="p">• Swinburne, Richard 2004
The Existence of God 2nd Edition</p>
<p class="p">Provisional Syllabus &amp;
Core Readings</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Introduction</p>
<p class="p">• James, William 1902 The
Varieties of Religious Experience Lectures XVI &amp; XVII</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. The epistemology
of religious experience I</p>
<p class="p">• Swinburne, Richard 2004
The Existence of God ch 13</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. The epistemology
of religious experience II</p>
<p class="p">• Alston, William 2004
‘Religious Experience Justifies Religious Belief’ in Michael Petersen and
Raymond VanArragon (eds.) Contemporary Debates in the Philosophy of Religion</p>
<p class="p">• Fales, Evan 2004 ‘Can
Mystics See God?’ in Michael Petersen and Raymond VanArragon (eds.)
Contemporary Debates in the Philosophy of Religion</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. God and perceptual
content</p>
<p class="p">• Zangwill, Nick 2004 ‘The
myth of religious experience’ Religious Studies</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Life after death
I: immaterialism</p>
<p class="p">• Davies, Brian 1993 An
Introduction to the Philosophy of Religion ch 11</p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Life After Death
II: materialism</p>
<p class="p">• Olson, Eric 2010
‘Immanent Causation and Life After Death’ in G. Gasser (ed) Personal Identity
and Resurrection</p>
<p class="p">Week 7. Immortality.</p>
<p class="p">• Williams, Bernard 1973
‘The Makropulos case: reflections on the tedium of immortality’ in his Problems
of the Self</p>
<p class="p">Week 8. Cosmological and
fine-tuning arguments</p>
<p class="p">• Parfit, Derek 1998 ‘Why
Anything? Why this?’ Reprinted in On What Matters Appendix D</p>
<p class="p">Week 9. The fine-tuning
argument in more detail</p>
<p class="p">• Swinburne, Richard 2003
‘The Argument to God from Fine-Tuning Argument Reassessed’ in Neil Manson ed.
God and Design</p>
<p class="p">Week 10. Fine-tuning and
the many-worlds hypothesis</p>
<p class="p">• White, Roger 2000
‘Fine-Tuning and Multiple Universes’ Nous</p>
<p class="p">Sample Essay Questions:</p>
<p class="p">• 'Scepticism about religious experience leads to
scepticism about ordinary sensory experience.' Discuss.</p>
<p class="p">• Does the diversity of religious experience undermine its
evidential force?</p>
<p class="p">• Is it a good thing that we are not immortal?</p>
<p class="p">• How, if at all, can a materialist about human persons make
sense of the possibility of life after death?</p>
<p class="p">• 'The theistic argument from cosmic fine-tuning is no
better than traditional arguments from design' Discuss.</p>
<p class="p">• Is it a mistake to suppose that fine-tuning proves
evidence for the existence of many universes? </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3062 Metaphysics of Science</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Luke Fenton-Glynn<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"><br />
Description: <br /></p>
<p class="p">In this course, we will cover three central topics in the metaphysics of science: causation, chance and the laws of nature. Questions to be addressed include: What are laws of nature? Are there laws other than those described by physics (for instance, are there laws of biology, meteorology, or economics)? What is the nature of chance (objective probability)? If so, do only fundamental physical laws (for example, those of quantum mechanics) generate chances, or do the laws or generalizations of biology, etc. yield chances? What is causation? How does causation relate to chance?</p>
<p class="p">No background in science or probability theory is needed for this course.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading:</p>
<p class="p">• Fenton-Glynn, L. (2015): ‘A Simple Introduction to
Probability’ &lt;
https://www.academia.edu/12094718/A_Simple_Introduction_to_Probability&gt;.</p>
<p class="p">• Paul, L. A. and Hall, N. (2013): Causation: A User’s
Guide (Oxford: OUP)</p>
<p class="p">• Armstrong, D. (1983): What is a Law of Nature? (Cambridge:
CUP).</p>
<p class="p">• Psillos, S. (2002): Causation and Explanation (Montreal:
McGill-Queen’s University Press).</p>
<p class="p">• Hájek, Alan (2012): ‘Interpretations of Probability’,
The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p">• Woodward, J. (2005): Making Things Happen (Oxford: OUP)</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Topic 1. Causation,
Regularities, and Counterfactuals</p>
<p class="p">• Mackie, J. (1965): 'Causes and Conditions', American
Philosophical Quarterly, Vol. 2, pp. 245-264.</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. ‘Causation’, Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 70,
pp. 556-557.</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, David (1986): 'Postscripts to
&quot;Causation&quot;'. In his Philosophical Papers, Vol. II (New York: OUP),
pp. 172-213. Postscript E: 'Redundant Causation'.</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. ‘Causation as Influence’, in J. Collins, N.
Hall, and L. A. Paul (eds.): Causation and Counterfactuals (Cambridge, MA: MIT
Press), pp. 76-106.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 2. Causation and
Structural Equations</p>
<p class="p">• Hitchcock, C. (2001): ‘The Intransitivity of Causation
Revealed in Equations and Graphs’, Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 98, pp. 273-299.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 3. Causation and
Probability</p>
<p class="p">• Hitchcock, C. (2004): ‘Do All and Only Causes Raise the
Probability of Effects?’, in J. Collins, N. Hall, and L.A. Paul (eds):
Causation and Counterfactuals (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press).</p>
<p class="p">Topic 4. Causation,
Probability, and Causal Models</p>
<p class="p">• Hitchcock, C. (2001): ‘A Tale of Two Effects’,
Philosophical Review, Vol. 110, pp. 361-396.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 5. Interpretations
of Probability</p>
<p class="p">• Hájek, Alan (2012): &quot;Interpretations of
Probability&quot;, The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 6. Problems with the
Naïve Regularity Theory of Laws</p>
<p class="p">• Armstrong, D. (1983): What is a Law of Nature?
(Cambridge: CUP), pp. 11-59.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 7. The Best System
Analysis of Laws and Chance</p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1994): ‘Humean Supervenience Debugged’, Mind,
Vol. 103, Sections 2-4 only.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 8. Special Sciences</p>
<p class="p">• Oppenheim, P. and Putnam, H. (1958): 'Unity of Science
as a Working Hypothesis', , in H. Feigl et al., eds., Minnesota Studies in the
Philosophy of Science, vol. 2 (Minneapolis: Minnesota University Press), pp.
3-36.</p>
<p class="p">• Fodor, J. (1974): ‘Special Sciences (Or: The Disunity of
Science as a Working Hypothesis)’, Synthese, Vol. 28, pp. 97-115.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 9. Invariant
Generalisations</p>
<p class="p">• Woodward, J. and Hitchcock, C. (2003): ‘Explanatory
Generalizations, Part I: A Counterfactual Account’, Noûs, Vol. 37, pp. 1-24.</p>
<p class="p">Topic 10. Special
Sciences, Statistical Mechanics, &amp; The Direction of Time</p>
<p class="p">• Loewer, B. (2012): 'Two Accounts of Laws and Time',
Philosophical Studies, Vol. 160, pp. 115-137.</p>
<p class="p">• Loewer, B. (2012): 'The Emergence of Time's Arrows and
Special Science Laws From Physics', Interface Focus, Vol. 2, pp. 13-19.</p>
<p class="p">Sample questions:</p>
<p class="p">• Are laws of nature mere regularities? </p>
<p class="p">• Are the generalisations of the special sciences (e.g.
biology, chemistry, economics) genuine laws of nature?</p>
<p class="p">• Are the special sciences reducible to physics?</p>
<p class="p">• Is all probability subjective, or are there objective
probabilities in the world?</p>
<p class="p">• Can causation be understood in terms of probabilistic
relations between events? </p>
<p class="p">• Can structural equations approaches to causation help us
overcome the difficulties facing more traditional philosophical accounts of
causation?</p>
<p class="p">• Can the direction of causation and the direction of time
be reduced to the direction of entropy increase? </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3067 Philosophy of Art</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Sebastian Gardner<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br />The course examines issues in aesthetics and the philosophy of art in classical German philosophy. Topics covered include: the concept of art's autonomy and its C18 origins; Kant's account of judgements of taste and his theory of art; Schiller's aesthetic solution to the problem of Freedom and Nature in his Letters on Aesthetic Education; aesthetic absolutism in Schelling and the early German Romantics; Hegel's system of art and thesis of the 'end' of art; theories of tragedy in classical German philosophy; and the challenge posed by modern(ist) art, and Danto's end-of-art theory. The two-hour class combines a lecture with discussion of the set text, which students are expected to have read with care and prepared their thoughts about beforehand.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3068 The Philosophical Foundations of Effective Altruism</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Joe Horton<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: B
<br />Assessment:Essay 3500 words<br />Capacity: 25</p>
<p class="p">Description: Effective Altruism is a relatively new social movement, but it has already had a significant impact. Its primary aim is to encourage people to use evidence and careful reasoning to do the most good possible with their charitable donations. An important secondary aim is to encourage people to give more to the most effective charities. In this course, we will consider a variety of philosophical questions and controversies surrounding the Effective Altruism movement. These questions include:</p>
<p class="p">Should we be Effective Altruists?</p>
<p class="p">What justifies Effective Altruism? — Must Effective Altruists be Utilitarians or Consequentialists, or can they also be Non-Consequentialists?</p>
<p class="p">What charitable causes do the most good?</p>
<p class="p">Should we buy products made in sweatshops?</p>
<p class="p">Should we care about human suffering more than animal suffering?</p>
<p class="p">Which matters more: ending poverty or controlling artificial intelligence?</p>
<p class="p">Should we prioritise preventing the suffering of people who are alive now over preventing the suffering of future generations?</p>
<p class="p">Does the threat of future human extinction matter for us here and now?</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3069 Free Speech and Theories of Autonomy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Robert Simpson<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: B
<br />Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />Capacity: 25</p>
<p class="p">Description: In this module we will examine the various conceptions of ‘autonomy’ that have been appealed to by philosophers and legal theorists as part of a defense of free speech principles. We will also survey some influential conceptions of autonomy that have been espoused by moral philosophers. Our overarching aim will be to consider how successful an autonomy-based defense of free speech is, or could be, and what the most persuasive or promising form of such a defense might involve.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3070 Metaethics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Mat Simpson<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: B
<br />Assessment: Essay 3500
<br />Capacity: 25 </p>
<p class="p"> Description: Metaethics involves questions about the nature of value and of ethical thought and language. In this course students will learn about four prominent metaethical theories – naturalism, non-naturalism, constructivism, and expressivism. They will then study four recent debates which each have interesting connections with other areas of philosophy – the question of whether moral judgements motivate, the evolutionary debunking of morality, moral testimony and disagreement, and the problem of creeping minimalism.</p>
<p class="p">Text include:</p>
<p class="p">Geoffrey Sayre-McCord, ed. Essays on Moral Realism Cornell University Press 1988</p>
<p class="p">Copp, David, ed. The Oxford Handbook of Ethical Theory. Oxford University Press, 2007.</p>
<p class="p">LaFollette, Hugh, ed. The Blackwell Guide to Ethical Theory. Oxford: Blackwell, 2000.</p>
<p class="p">Simon Blackburn, Ruling Passions (Oxford University Press 1998)</p>
<p class="p">Russ Shafer-Landu, ed. Oxford Studies in Metaethics (several volumes available, all contain relevant material.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3072 Representation and Reality</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Mat Simpson <br />Term: 1<br />Area: A
<br />Assessment: Essay 3500
<br />Capacity: 25 </p>
<p class="p"> Description: In this module we will investigate the relationship between the world and our representation of it by our language and thoughts. We will study a number of philosophical debates from the last century, which all center on the idea that our theories about human language and thought will in some way affect what we think about reality. Topics studied will include reference and non-existence objects, modality and causation, pragmatism about truth, non-representational theories of meaning and anti-metaphysical arguments. Text include:</p>
<p class="p">- Ian Hacking, 1975, Why Does Language Matter to Philosophy? (Cambridge University Press)</p>
<p class="p">- Amie Thomasson, 2015, Ontology Made Easy (Oxford University Press)</p>
<p class="p">- Steven Gross, Nicholas Tebbe and Michael Williams, eds., 2015, Meaning without Representation (Oxford University Press)</p>
<p class="p">- Huw Price, ed., 2013 Expressivism, Pragmatism and Representationalism, (Cambridge University Press)</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3082 Feminism and Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Amia
Srinivasan<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words (85%) Weekly reading responses (15%)<br />
Capacity: 50</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p"> This course will be an advanced introduction to
the philosophical issues raised and addressed by the ongoing fight for women's
liberation from patriarchal oppression. Topics include: the metaphysics of
gender, intersectionality, feminism and trans issues, feminist epistemology,
pornography, sex and sexual 'liberation', feminist critiques of liberalism and capitalism,
and the relationship between feminism and philosophy. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3084 20th Century Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Mark
Kalderon<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> </p>
<p class="p">20th
Century Philosophy is dedicated to reading great if neglected texts of the
twentieth century. The text varies year by year. This year we shall be reading Peter Geach’s Mental Acts. Mental Acts contains, inter alia, an influential critique of behaviourism and contains as well the kernel of the Frege-Geach objection to experessivism.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3087 Equality</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Han Van
Wietmarschen<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> There are many differences between us. I am
writing this, for example, and you are reading it. If you take this module, I
will decide what the readings are, and what we do in class. I will mark your
essays, and you will evaluate my teaching. Nonetheless, I am your equal. It should
treat you as my equal, and you should treat me as your equal. You are neither
my superior nor my inferior.</p>
<p class="p">What does it mean for us
to be equals? What would it take for each of us to be, and be regarded and
treated as, equals? What would a society be like if it were a society of
equals? Is equality a genuine moral or political ideal? In this course, we
investigate these questions, drawing on insights from philosophy, economics,
anthropology, sociology, and history.</p>
<p class="p">Examples of reading
materials:</p>
<p class="p">Thomas Hobbes: Leviathan</p>
<p class="p">J.J. Rousseau: Discourse
on Inequality</p>
<p class="p">Christopher Boehm:
Hierarchy in the Forest</p>
<p class="p">John Rawls: Theory of
Justice</p>
<p class="p">Ronald Dworkin: What is
Equality?</p>
<p class="p">James Whitman: Harsh
Justice</p>
<p class="p">Martha Nussbaum: Women and
Human Development: the Capabilities Approach</p>
<p class="p">Amartya Sen: Equality of
What?</p>
<p class="p">Elizabeth Anderson: What
is the point of equality?</p>
<p class="p">Samuel Scheffler: What is
Egalitarianism?</p>
<p class="p">Karl Marx: Capital</p>
<p class="p">Elizabeth Anderson: The
Imperative of Integration</p>
<p class="p">Tommie Shelby: We Who Are
Dark</p>
<p class="p">Erving Goffman: Stigma</p>
<p class="p">W.E.B. Du Bois: The Souls
of Black Folk </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3088 Formal Epistemology</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Luke Fenton-Glynn<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: 2 Sets of exercises (15% each) and Essay (2500 wds - 70%)<br />
Capacity: 25<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> </p>
<p class="p">Students will be introduced to the topic of formal epistemology. This will involve teaching the basic principles of probability theory, the arguments that have been given that a rational agent’s degrees of belief are represented by a probability function, and the arguments for and against principles that have been proposed concerning how a rational agent’s degrees of belief are constrained (both synchronically and in their evolution over time). Expected Utility Theory will also be introduced, and critically evaluated, as the orthodox decision theory for agents with probabilistic degrees of belief.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3089: Advanced Topics on Moral Philosophy: Responsibility, Luck and Excuses</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Ulrike Heuer</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 3500 words</p>
<p class="p">Capacity: 25</p>
<p class="p">Description: The module explores theories of responsibility in attempting to account for the grounds and the limits of what we are responsible for. In doing so the module will examine distinct conceptions of responsibility and some fundamental challenges that arise in relation to it (e.g. whether responsibility is an incoherent concept, or whether there is ‘moral luck’). In light of these general considerations the module will then aim to explore related topics, such as blameworthiness, excuses and collective responsibility. The fundamental aim is to understand the nature of responsibility, and the resources contemporary theoretic approaches may (or may not) have in attempting to account for our ways of ascribing actions to ourselves and others, and judging them.   </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3097 Topics in Moral Psychology</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Douglas
Lavin<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 3500 words<br />Capacity: 25</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> Investigation of a familiar and puzzling
elements of moral life, e.g., promising, forgiveness, authority, pride/shame,
pleasure, respect/humiliation, self-control, love and friendship,
competitiveness. Topics and texts may
differ year to year. <br />For more information please email <a href="mailto:d.lavin@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">d.lavin@ucl.ac.uk</a></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3098 Linguistic Semantics and the Philosophy of Language</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ethan Nowak<br />Term: 2 </p>
<p class="p">Area: A
<br />Assessment: Essay 2000 words (70%) and problem sets (30%)
Capacity: 25</p>
<p class="p">Description:<br />This module introduces the technical machinery of contemporary linguistic semantics, and explores the philosophical foundations and applications of the same. The module begins with an exploration of the significance of two ideas: a.) that knowing the truth conditions associated with an assertoric sentence is knowing its meaning and b.) that a theory of meaning for natural language must be compositional. The rest of the module is devoted to the construction of a formal theory that combines those ideas with the Fregean principle of type-driven interpretation to explain the behavior of simple sentences, relative clauses, quantificational constructions, demonstratives, and other philosophically-interesting expression types. Significant familiarity with formal methods is presupposed. Students who do not have experience with intermediate or advanced logic should consult the instructor before registering for this module.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3099 Dissertation</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Various<br />
Term: 1 and 2 (= 1 course unit)<br />
Area: A / B or C<br />
Assessment: Essay 8000<br />
Capacity: n/a<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">Description: <br />Enrolment requires approval by your personal tutor. A 8000-word essay on a philosophical topic approved by your personal tutor. Tuition involves four sessions of one-on-one supervision by a member of staff. The dissertation submission deadline is 1st day of 3rd term by 4.00 pm. Currently no pre-requisites and no prior grade requirement for the dissertation.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3100 Guided Research Module</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">· Open to final year
students only.</p>
<p class="p">· Open only to
students taking single-honours Philosophy or a combined honours degree
involving Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p">0.5 credit units</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Module Aims: </strong>To provide students with an
understanding of an area of current philosophical research and to offer them
the opportunity of engaging in the methodology of philosophical research
practiced in leading research universities in the world. The student should
gain experience of the method of study and instruction expected of a graduate
student in the first years of a research degree.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Intended Learning Outcomes: </strong>The student
will produce a significant piece of writing in the relevant research area. The
student will gain an understanding of the key issues in that area of the
discipline, and will encounter some of the core classical readings and/or some
of the most important recent literature on the topic. They will gain an
understanding of research methods in philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Module Structure: </strong>Students who meet the eligibility
criteria outlined below can, subject to space and with approval of the
Departmental Tutor and the module leader, select a graduate-level module from
among the following options:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>PHILG010: Research
Seminar: 19th Century Philosophy (T. Stern; Term 2; Group C) </li>
<li>PHILG013: Graduate Studies in Philosophy of Action (D. Lavin; Term 1; Group A)</li>
<li>PHILG020: Graduate Studies in Philosophy of Mind (M. Martin; Term 2; Group A)</li>
<li>PHILG026: Research Seminar: Recent Work in Political Philosophy (H. Wietmarschen; Term 2; Group B)</li>
<li>PHILG030: The
Self in Early Analytic Philosophy (R. Madden; Term 1; Group A)</li>
<li>PHILG053: Perception and Its Objects (M. Kalderon; Term 1; Group A)</li>
<li>PHILG067: Philosophy Politics &amp; Economics of Health (J. Wilson; Term 1; Group B)</li>
<li>PHILG090: Graduate
Studies in Ethics and Political Philosophy (V. Munoz-Dardé; Term 2; Group B)</li>
<li>PHILG095:
Recent Work in Practical Philosophy (D. Lavin; Term 2; Group B)</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"><strong>Tuition: </strong>Students will attend all
seminars for the module that they select. In recognition of the fact that
graduate-level courses are more demanding than undergraduate courses,
undergraduates taking the Guided Research Module (GRM) will receive additional
support in the form of three tutorials (i.e. small group meetings) with the
leader of the graduate module.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment: </strong>Students will<strong> </strong>complete
a summative essay of the same length as the graduate students (4,500 words) due
for submission on the first day of the term following the term in which the
module is taken. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Eligibility and Selection: </strong>To be
eligible for the GRM students must have a weighted average of at least 65 in
the modules they have taken in their first and second year (modules taken in
the second year are weighted three times as heavily as first year modules). A
maximum of two undergraduate students may take each of the modules listed above
(this may be fewer if the module is oversubscribed, since graduate students
will be given priority). In the event that more than two undergraduates with a
weighted average of 65 or above apply to take the same graduate module (or more
than one if there’s only space for one undergraduate on the module), then the
students with the highest weighted averages will be selected.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHIL3101 Advanced Tutorials</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Various - Convenor Fiona Leigh<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A, B or C<br />
Assessment: Participation in class (10%) <br />Presentations (15%) <br />Essay (3000 words = 75%)</p>
<p class="p">Description: This module is designed to allow students to build on their introductory tutorial module. Students will discuss a variety of central philosophical texts on fundamental topics in a broad area of their choice. The module will allow them to enhance their skills in philosophical discussion, oral presentation and essay writing. Students will be placed in tutorial groups of around five, ensuring that everyone has a chance to participate in debate, and to receive feedback on their oral presentations and written work during the course. The texts studied will be selected by the course tutor in consultation with the module convenor.</p>
<p class="p"> Students enrolled in the 3<sup>rd</sup> Year Tutorial
Module, are asked to nominate their top two preferences for the kind of
philosophy to be studied in the module, either Theoretical Philosophy (A),
Practical Philosophy (B), or Historical Philosophy (C). The Department will
endeavour to allocate students to one of their top two preferences, wherever
possible. Students will be allocated to an instructor (a Postgraduate Teaching Assistant),
and in the first week of class (or possibly in the week before), will be given
a syllabus and reading list. During the semester students will in alternate
weeks present or read aloud draft essays (of about 2000 words) to the small
group, in response to the overarching topic and in light of the reading list.
The group will then discuss the work critically and offer suggestions for
improvement, or indicate further questions or lines of inquiry. The assessment
will be a 3,000 word essay produced as a result of the draft essays discussed
during the semester.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>


<p class="p"><br />In addition BA Philosophy students can take the following modules in ESPS (European Social and Political Studies) as Philosophy modules (i.e. do not count as a module from another department): </p>

<p class="p">For more information about the ESPS modules above please see the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/esps/study/european-social-political-studies-ba/courses-2017-18" target="_blank">ESPS website</a>.</p>


<h3 class="heading">Information for UCL students from other departments: </h3>




<p class="p">The following modules can only be taken by students studying Philosophy degrees (Single and Combined Honours):
<strong>PHIL1017: Philosophy Tutorials</strong> / <strong>PHIL3TBD Dissertation/ PHIL3101 Advanced Tutorials and PHIL3100 Guided Research Module.</strong></p>
<p class="p">
Registration for all modules is via Portico. Once Philosophy students have registered their modules spare places will be allocated on a first come first served basis. <br /></p>
<p class="p">All modules are half-units (0.5 UCL credit = 7.5 ECTS). Modules that are coded PHIL1_ and PHIL2_ have a compulsory weekly seminar in addition to the weekly lectures. The semiars are automatically allocated via the common timetable to fit
with your module choices once the module selection has been approved by both departments. PHIL3_ modules run as 2 hour weekly seminars, some have a fortnightly discussion class as well.<br /></p>
<p class="p">Modules that begin PHIL1___ are introductory level; modules that begin with PHIL2___ are intermediate level primarily for second year students; modules that begin with
PHIL3___ are advanced courses.</p>

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";

  doc.close();
})();

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">BA Key Contacts</h1>
<p class="p">The Undergraduate Programme Administrator <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people/administrative-staff" target="_self">Cassilda Alcobia-Murphy</a> is the first point of contact for enquiries about:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Module Changes</li>
<li>Seminars Amendments</li>
<li>Applying for Extenuating circumstances</li>
<li>Absence reporting </li>
</ul>
<p class="p">Personal tutors contacts are available <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people/permanent-academic-staff" target="_self">here</a>, they should be contacted about the following:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Feedback on overall academic progress</li>
<li>Advice on module selection</li>
<li>Pastoral help (issues that are having a minor effect on their studies - i.e. not likely to require an interruption of studies, withdrawal from degree programme, or have a major impact on exams/coursework)</li>
<li>Advice on course requirements and regulations</li>
<li>Reference requests


</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">Students should contact the Departmental Tutor, <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people/permanent-academic-staff/luke-fenton-glynn" target="_self">Luke Fenton-Glynn</a>, about the following:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Changes to registration status (requests to change degree programmes, interrupt studies, withdraw from their degree programme).</li>
<li>Pastoral issues that are likely to have a major effect on their studies (perhaps requiring an interruption of studies, alternative assessment, an extended absence from UCL, etc.)</li>
<li>When referred to departmental tutor by their personal tutor/department office.</li>
<li>If the student has an issue which they feel hasn't been adequately addressed by their personal tutor.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">BA students can also contact their <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/staff-student-consultative-committee" target="_blank">student academic representative (StAR)</a> about matters they would like discussed at the staff-student consultative committee. </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />

                //if old browser load the shiv
                ,nope : [

            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: []//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';
            }
        </script> 

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/require.min.js"></script>

  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {

  };

  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Coursework Penalties</h1>
<p class="p"><strong>Lateness penalties for Undergraduate and Postgraduate (Taught) essays:</strong></p>
<p class="p">Planning, time-management and the meeting of deadlines are
part of the personal and professional skills expected of all graduates. For
this reason, UCL expects students to submit all coursework by the published
deadline date and time, after which penalties will be applied.</p>
<p class="p">If a student experiences something which prevents them from
meeting a deadline that is sudden, unexpected, significantly disruptive and
beyond their control, they should submit an Extenuating Circumstances (EC) Form.
If the request is accepted, the student may be granted an extension. If the
deadline has already passed, the late submission may be condoned i.e. there
will be no penalty for submitting late.</p>
<p class="p">Further information:</p>




<h5 class="heading"></h5>


<p class="p">· <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/silva/srs/academic-manual/c4/module-assessment#3.11" target="_blank">Late Submission Penalties</a></p>
<p class="p">· <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/srs/academic-manual/extenuating-circumstances">Extenuating Circumstances</a></p>
<p class="p"><strong><br />Penalties for over-length coursework, including dissertations:</strong> <br /></p>
<p class="p">Assessed work should not exceed the prescribed word count. </p>
<p class="p">References and footnotes count towards the word limit; the bibliography, title and cover sheet do not.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>For work that exceeds a specified maximum length by less than 10% the mark will be reduced by five percentage marks, but the penalised mark will not be reduced below the pass mark, assuming the work merited a Pass.</li>
<li>For work that exceeds a specified maximum length by 10% or more the mark will be reduced by ten percentage marks, but the penalised mark will not be reduced below the pass mark, assuming the work merited a Pass.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"><strong><br />Minimum Length</strong></p>
<p class="p">Please note there is no automatic penalty for under-length essays <strong>providing there is sufficient suitable content</strong>.</p>
<p class="p"><strong><br />Reuse of material</strong></p>
<p class="p">Any paper submitted by you is presumed to be original work that has not previously been submitted for another course. You should therefore, as a rule, avoid writing on topics that you have written on previously. If you consider that there is good reason for you to revisit a topic, or to overlap with previously submitted work, then you must consult, and obtain prior written approval from the course tutor. If permission is granted, the onus will nevertheless remain on you to avoid mere duplication.<br /></p>
<p class="p"><strong><br />Plagiarism</strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/current-students/guidelines/plagiarism" target="_self">Read UCL central information on plagiarism</a></li>
</ul>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/modernizr-custom.js"></script>

       

        <script>
            var cuttingTheMustard = document.querySelector && window.localStorage && window.addEventListener;

            Modernizr.load({
                //cutting the mustard as used by the BBC
                test : cuttingTheMustard
                //if old browser load the shiv
                ,nope : [
                    '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.proxy.min.js'
                ]
            });
            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: []//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';
            }
        </script> 

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/require.min.js"></script>
        <script src='//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/main.js'></script>
        <script>require(['app/general','theme/indigo-autocomplete-ga','theme/silva','app/searchWithAutoComplete','app/lightbox',]);//load the default stuff</script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">MA Programmes</h1>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://moodle.ucl.ac.uk/mod/book/view.php?id=1627295" target="_self">MA Handbook</a>: This guide in Moodle contains all the essential information for students on both the MA Philosophy and MA PPE Heath.
</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/ma-programmes/ma-modules" target="_self">MA Modules</a> 2017/18: List of modules running with descriptions.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/ma-programmes/key-contacts" target="_self">Key Contacts</a>: Who to get in touch with for various taught Master's enquiries.</li>
<li>MA Philosophy Timetable for <a href="https://timetable.ucl.ac.uk/tt/deptTimet.do?firstReq=N&amp;deptId=PHIL&amp;deptYear=G&amp;weekRange=5-16&amp;temporalView=week" target="_self">Term 1</a> and <a href="https://timetable.ucl.ac.uk/tt/deptTimet.do?firstReq=N&amp;deptId=PHIL&amp;deptYear=G&amp;weekRange=20-30&amp;temporalView=week" target="_self">Term 2</a> of the 2015/16 academic year</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students" target="_self">Forms and information</a> for all UCL Philosophy students.</li>
<li><p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/ma-programmes/ma-supervision-list">Supervision list</a> for MA Philosophy dissertations.</p>
<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/images/indigo/SeminarRPW4.jpg" width="600" height="604" alt="Professor O'Brien in Seminar" class="medium-image float-right" title="Professor O'Brien in Seminar" /></li>
</ul>


<h3 class="heading">MA Dissertation Information:</h3>




<p class="p">Two copies of your MA dissertation are due in the Departmental Office by 4pm on <strong>Friday 1 September 2017</strong>.<br /><br />You also need to submit this on the <a href="https://moodle.ucl.ac.uk/mod/turnitintooltwo/view.php?id=2983585" target="_blank">Moodle</a> site by this deadline too.</p>


<h3 class="heading">Format</h3>




<p class="p">Dissertations should be handed in as follows:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Two copies, not in a folder, but with the pages of each copy well secured (e.g. stapled or bound) and including the Cover Sheet (link below).</li>
<li>Download Cover Sheet (<a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/docs/coversheet.doc" target="_blank">Word doc</a>). The module code for the MA Philosophy dissertation is PHILGA99.</li>
<li>Your dissertation should have a clear bibliography at the end listing all works you have referred to or quoted from.</li>
<li>Do not include your name anywhere in the dissertation (hard copy or Moodle upload).</li>
</ul>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />

        <script>
            var cuttingTheMustard = document.querySelector && window.localStorage && window.addEventListener;

            Modernizr.load({
                //cutting the mustard as used by the BBC
                test : cuttingTheMustard
                //if old browser load the shiv
                ,nope : [
                    '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.min.js'
                    ,'//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/respond.proxy.min.js'
                ]
            });
            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: []//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';
            }
        </script> 

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/require.min.js"></script>
        <script src='//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/main.js'></script>
        <script>require(['app/general','theme/indigo-autocomplete-ga','theme/silva','app/searchWithAutoComplete','app/lightbox',]);//load the default stuff</script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">MA Key Contacts</h1>
<p class="p">The Graduate Programme Administrator, Richard Edwards, is the first point of contact for all enquiries about the MA programmes in the Philosophy Department.</p>
<p class="p">Personal tutors contacts are available <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people" target="_self">here</a>, they should be contacted about the following:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Feedback on overall academic progress</li>
<li>Advice on module selection</li>
<li>Pastoral help (issues that are having a minor effect on their studies - i.e. not likely to require an interruption of studies, withdrawal from degree programme, or have a major impact on exams/coursework)</li>
<li>Advice on course requirements and regulations</li>
<li>Reference requests</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">Students should contact the MA Tutor, <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people/permanent-academic-staff/ulrike-heuer">Ulrike Heuer</a> about the following:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Changes to registration status (requests to change degree programmes, interrupt studies, withdraw from their degree programme).</li>
<li>Pastoral issues that are likely to have a major effect on their studies (perhaps requiring an interruption of studies, alternative assessment, an extended absence from UCL, etc.)</li>
<li>When referred to departmental tutor by their personal tutor/department office.</li>
<li>If the student has an issue which they feel hasn't been adequately addressed by their personal tutor.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">MA students can also contact their <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/staff-student-consultative-committee" target="_blank">student academic representative (StAR)</a> about matters they would like discussed at the staff-student consultative committee. </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
