                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">MA Modules</h1>
<p class="p"> Below is the list of modules running in the 2017/18 academic year - click on the title for more information. Module leader email addresses can be found via the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/people/permanent-academic-staff">staff pages</a>:</p>
<p class="p">For times and locations please use the <a href="https://timetable.ucl.ac.uk/tt/homePage.do" target="_blank">UCL common timetable</a>.<br /></p>






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA00: Advanced Topics on Moral Philosophy: Responsibility, Luck and Excuses</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ulrike Heuer</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500 words</p>
<p class="p">Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">The module explores theories
of responsibility in attempting to account for the grounds and the limits of
what we are responsible for. In doing so the module will examine distinct
conceptions of responsibility and some fundamental challenges that arise in
relation to it (e.g. whether responsibility is an incoherent concept, or
whether there is ‘moral luck’). In light of these general considerations the
module will then aim to explore related topics, such as blameworthiness,
excuses and collective responsibility. The fundamental aim is to understand the
nature of responsibility, and the resources contemporary theoretic approaches
may (or may not) have in attempting to account for our ways of ascribing
actions to ourselves and others, and judging them.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA04	Global Justice and Health</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: James Wilson<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This module explores ethical questions in global
health by connecting the literature in global health with recent writings in
moral and political philosophy. The first half raises some more general issues
about global inequalities in health and their causes, and then explores some
central issues in moral and political philosophy, including the normative
significance of nations, and human rights approaches to health. The second half
looks at some more specific issues where philosophers have contributed to
debates in global health, including the ethics of research in developing
countries and access to pharmaceuticals. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA08 Early Wittgenstein</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: José Zalabardo<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: C<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> The purpose of this course is to present some of
the central doctrines of Wittgenstein’s Tractatus-: the Tractarian Account of
Representation and Reality (TARR). We can characterise TARR as involving three
main components.</p>
<p class="p">The first component of TARR
is the view that everyday propositions don’t represent the world directly: they
represent the world through the mediation of a class of postulated
propositions, known as elementary propositions (Elementarsätze). Everyday
propositions represent the world by being truth functions of elementary
propositions.</p>
<p class="p">The second component of TARR
is an account of the nature of elementary propositions and of how they
represent the world. On this account, an elementary proposition is a
combination of items known as names. Names are referential expressions. An
elementary proposition represents the referents of its names as combined with
one another in the same way in which the names are combined in the proposition.
The proposition is true if the referents are so combined; false if they are
not. The referents of names are simple items known as objects. The combinations
of objects that elementary propositions represent as obtaining are known as
states of affairs (Sachverhalte).</p>
<p class="p">The third component of TARR
is an account of the structure of reality, according to which a possible state
of the world is constituted by the states of affairs that obtain in it. Two
states of the world differ from one another only if there are states of affairs
that obtain in one and not in the other. And for every set of states of affairs
there is a possible state of the world in which the states of affairs that
obtain are precisely the elements of the set.</p>
<p class="p">Thus, according to TARR,
elementary propositions and states of affairs provide the interface between
language and the world. Propositions represent the world by their
truth-functional dependence on elementary propositions. These, in turn,
represent states of affairs. This enables propositions to represent the whole
of reality, since everything that is the case, and everything that can be the
case, consists in the obtaining and non-obtaining of states of affairs—what
truth functions of elementary propositions represent.</p>
<p class="p">Taken as an intuitive model,
TARR is fairly easy to understand—we can form a conception of what things would
have to be like in order for TARR to be correct. A precise, literal
understanding of the view is much harder to achieve. And it is even harder to
grasp why anyone would think that this is how things are in actuality—that language
and reality have the structure that TARR attributes to them and that the former
represents the latter as TARR says it does. Specifically, it is hard to
understand why Wittgenstein thought this. Addressing these questions is the
main goal of this course.</p>
<p class="p">The lectures will be based on
a book I’m writing on the topic: Representation and Reality in Wittgenstein’s
Tractatus. It’s available to students on Moodle. Please do not circulate
without permission.</p>
<p class="p">TOPICS</p>
<p class="p">1. Russell’s dual-relation
theory of judgment</p>
<p class="p">2. Russell’s
multiple-relation theory of judgment</p>
<p class="p">3. Russell and Wittgenstein
on forms</p>
<p class="p">4. Wittgenstein’s picture
theory</p>
<p class="p">5. Frege on unity and
unsaturatedness</p>
<p class="p">6. Wittgenstein on the unity
of the proposition</p>
<p class="p">7. Wittgenstein on the unity
of facts</p>
<p class="p">8. Objects and expressions as
common structural features</p>
<p class="p">9. Substance and simplicity</p>
<p class="p">READINGS</p>
<p class="p">Primary sources</p>
<p class="p">Wittgenstein</p>
<p class="p">There are two main English
translations of the Tractatus, one by by C. K. Ogden (London: Routledge and
Kegan Paul, 1922), and one by David Pears and Brian McGuinness (London:
Routledge and Kegan Paul, 2nd ed.1974). I tend to use the Pears and McGuinness,
but although they differ in important respects, either would be fine.</p>
<p class="p">I have prepared a hypertext
version of the Pears and McGuinness translation. It doesn't work on some
browsers.</p>
<p class="p">If you know any German, there
is a very useful edition by Joachim Schulte and Brian McGuinness (Frankfurt am
Main: Suhrkamp, 1989), collating sections of the Tractatus with relevant
passages from preliminary manuscripts.</p>
<p class="p">Another important primary
source is Wittgenstein's Notebooks, 1914-1916 (Oxford: Blackwell, 2nd ed.1979).
This volume contains the main extant manuscripts from the period when
Wittgenstein was working on the Tractatus.</p>
<p class="p">Frege and Russell</p>
<p class="p">We will be paying close
attention to the origin of Wittgenstein's ideas in the work of Russell and
Frege. We will be looking mainly at the following texts:</p>
<p class="p">For Frege, &quot;Function and
Concept&quot; and &quot;On Concept and Object&quot;, both translated in
Translations from the Philosophical Writings of Gottlob Frege, edited by Max
Black and P. T. Geach, Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1980.</p>
<p class="p">And for Russell:</p>
<p class="p">Chapter 4 of The Principles
of Mathematics. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1903.</p>
<p class="p">&quot;On the Nature of Truth
and Falsehood.&quot; In Philosophical Essays, 147-59. London: Longmans, Green,
1910.</p>
<p class="p">Chapter 12 of The Problems of
Philosophy . London: Williams &amp; Norgate, 1912.</p>
<p class="p">&quot;Theory of Knowledge:
The 1913 Manuscript.&quot; In The Collected Papers of Bertrand Russell. Vol 7,
edited by Elizabeth Ramsden Eames and Kenneth Blackwell. London: Allen &amp;
Unwin, 1984. (Part I, Chapters VII and IX, and Part II, Chapters I and V)</p>
<p class="p">The fourth lecture of The
Philosophy of Logical Atomism. LaSalle, Ill.: Open Court, 1985.</p>
<p class="p">Secondary sources</p>
<p class="p">Books</p>
<p class="p">There are many book-length
expositions and commentaries of the Tractatus. Many of them make some good
points but they all differ in important respects from the interpretation that
I'll be presenting. The following might be particularly useful:</p>
<p class="p">Max Black. A Companion to
Wittgenstein's Tractatus. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1964.</p>
<p class="p">James Griffin. Wittgenstein's
Logical Atomism. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1964.</p>
<p class="p">David Pears. The False
Prison: A Study of the Development of Wittgenstein's Philosophy. Volume I.
Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1987.</p>
<p class="p">Articles and book chapters</p>
<p class="p">I will recommend readings on
particular topics in the lectures, but here is an unsystematic selection of
interesting articles on the issues that we will be discussing:</p>
<p class="p">Candlish, Stewart. &quot;The
Unity of the Proposition and Russell's Theories of Judgment.&quot; In Bertrand
Russell and the Origins of Analytical Philosophy, edited by Ray Monk and
Anthony Palmer, 103-35. Bristol: Thoemmes Press, 1996.</p>
<p class="p">Conant, James.
&quot;Elucidation and Nonsense in Frege and Early Wittgenstein.&quot; In The
New Wittgenstein, edited by Alice Crary and Rupert Read, 174-217. London:
Routledge, 2000.</p>
<p class="p">----. &quot;The Search for
Logically Alien Thought: Descartes, Kant, Frege, and the Tractatus.&quot;
Philosophical Topics 20 (1992): 115-80.</p>
<p class="p">---. &quot;Two Conceptions of
Die Überwindung der Metaphysik. Carnap and Early Wittgenstein.&quot; In
Wittgenstein in America, edited by Timothy McCarthy and Sean C. Stidd, 13-61.
Oxford: Clarendon, 2001.</p>
<p class="p">Geach, Peter T. &quot;Saying
and Showing in Frege and Wittgenstein.&quot; Acta Philosophica Fennica 28
(1976): 54-70.</p>
<p class="p">Griffin, Nicholas.
&quot;Russell's Multiple Relation Theory of Judgement.&quot; Philosophical
Studies 47 (1985): 213-48.</p>
<p class="p">---. &quot;Wittgenstein's
Criticism of Russell's Theory of Judgment.&quot; Russell 5 (1986): 132-45.</p>
<p class="p">Hylton, Peter. &quot;The
Nature of the Proposition and the Revolt against Idealism.&quot; In Philosophy
in History, edited by Richard Rorty, J. B. Schneewind and Quentin Skinner,
375-97. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1984.</p>
<p class="p">---. Russell, Idealism, and
the Emergence of Analytic Philosophy. Oxford: Clarendon, 1990.</p>
<p class="p">Ishiguro, Hidé. &quot;Use and
Reference of Names.&quot; In Studies in the Philosophy of Wittgenstein, edited
by Peter Guy Winch, 20-50. London: Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul, 1969.</p>
<p class="p">Kremer, Michael. &quot;Contextualism
and Holism in the Early Wittgenstein: From Prototractatus to Tractatus .&quot;
Philosophical Topics 25 (1997): 87-120.</p>
<p class="p">Linsky, Leonard. &quot;The
Unity of the Proposition.&quot; Journal of the History of Philosophy 30 (1992):
243-73.</p>
<p class="p">Palmer, Anthony. Concept and
Object: The Unity of the Proposition in Logic and Psychology . London:
Routledge, 1988. (Chapter 4)</p>
<p class="p">Pears, David. &quot;The
Relation between Wittgenstein's Picture Theory of Propositions and Russell's
Theory of Judgment.&quot; Philosophical Review 86 (1977): 177-96.</p>
<p class="p">Proops, Ian.
&quot;Wittgenstein on the Substance of the World.&quot; European Journal of
Philosophy 12 (2004): 106-26.</p>
<p class="p">Sluga, Hans. &quot;Frege
against the Booleans.&quot; Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic 28 (1987):
80-98.</p>
<p class="p">Sommerville, Stephen.
&quot;Wittgenstein to Russell (July, 1913). 'I am very sorry to hear ... my
objection paralyses you'.&quot; In Language, Logic, and Philosophy: Proceedings
of the 4th International Wittgenstein Symposium , edited by Rudolf Haller and
Wolfgang Grassl, 182-87. Vienna: Holder-Pichler-Tempsky, 1980. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA11 Research Preparation in Philosophy 1</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Lucy O'Brien</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Area: n/a</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: n</p>
<p class="p">This course will introduce
UCL Philosophy Masters students to graduate study in philosophy and to
philosophical discussion. Each week all
students will have read in advance a classic piece of analytic philosophy, and
one student will give an oral presentation to initiate a discussion of the
reading, which is moderated by the convenor.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA12 Research Preparation in Philosophy 2</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Sebastian
Gardner</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: n/a</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Exam 2hr</p>
<p class="p">Shared: n</p>
<p class="p">This course builds on
PHILGA11 and continues to train UCL Philosophy MA students in the critical
interpretation and analysis of philosophical texts, and in the practice of
philosophical discussion. Each week is devoted to a different topic or problem,
drawn from a variety of areas. Students are expected to complete the reading –
usually two items, which may be classic papers or short historical texts – and
to prepare their thoughts in advance. Two students give an oral presentation to
initiate the discussion, which is moderated by the convenor, and to which all
are expected to contribute.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA13 Advanced Topics in Political Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Véronique
Munoz-Dardé</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">This year’s topic is <strong>intimate markets</strong>. The course will raise and pursue a number of questions including: Are some markets morally noxious? Should some things not be for sale (for example, surrogacy, sexual services, body parts)? Is there such a thing as self-ownership? How, if at all, does the idea of self-ownership explain, or offer a critique of the notion of intimate markets?</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Note</strong> that some of the materials in this course overlap with those discussed in last year’s Regulation of Intimacy. For that reason, this course is not open to students who have previously taken that course. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA14 Topics in Greek Philosophy: Aristotle</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Fiona Leigh</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: C</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">The course focuses on
Aristotle’s philosophy of mind and moral psychology. After an brief
introduction in the first week to the central tenets of his metaphysics and
epistemology, the course will cover topics including Aristotle's views human
nature and human flourishing, the kinds of cognitive capacities attributable to
humans and non-human animals, the emotions, virtue ethics, the doctrine of the
mean and learning to be good, weakness of the will, and the role of
contemplation in the good life. The central primary texts will be de Anima and
the Nicomachean Ethics, although other texts will be consulted. A sample
syllabi, with the relevant primary texts, is as follows:</p>
<p class="p">Week 1</p>
<p class="p">Introduction – overview of
life and works, relation to Plato – and Aristotle’s metaphysics: hylomorphism,
substance, the four causes, body and soul</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Metaphysics,
VII.1-4, 6, 10-11, 13, 15, 17; Physics II.1-9; III.1-3, VIII.6; de Anima, book
1</p>
<p class="p">Week 2</p>
<p class="p">Eudaimonia &amp; Function </p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Nicomachean
Ethics, book I (especially chapters 1-5, 7-9, 13)</p>
<p class="p">Week 3</p>
<p class="p">The Soul &amp; Cognition</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: de Anima, books
I-III (especially I.1, I.4, II.1-6, II.11-12, III.1-3), and de Motu Animalium,
6-11 </p>
<p class="p">Week 4</p>
<p class="p">Phantasia &amp; Emotion</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Rhetoric book
II; de Anima, III.3 </p>
<p class="p">Week 5</p>
<p class="p">Habituation, Pleasure &amp;
Cognition</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Nicomachean
Ethics, I.13, II.1-3, (II.4-9: optional), X.9</p>
<p class="p">Week 6</p>
<p class="p">Habituation &amp; Action</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Nicomachean
Ethics, II.4 (in detail)</p>
<p class="p">Week 7</p>
<p class="p">The Doctrine of the Mean</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Nicomachean
Ethics, books II-III (especially II.1-9, III.5-12)</p>
<p class="p">Week 8</p>
<p class="p">The Mean Relative to Us </p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: (as for last
week:) Nicomachean Ethics, books II-III (esp. II.1-9, III.5-12), and VI.1-2,
5-6 (optional)</p>
<p class="p">Week 9</p>
<p class="p">Virtue and Akrasia (weakness
of the will)</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Nicomachean
Ethics, VII.1-10 </p>
<p class="p">Week 10</p>
<p class="p">Two kinds of flourishing?</p>
<p class="p">Primary Text: Nicomachean
Ethics, book X (especially X.6-8)</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA16 Advanced Class in the Philosophy of Mind</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Lucy O'Brien<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This module is concerned to explore the ways in
which subjects are conscious of themselves. The first six weeks will be
concerned to consider and critically evaluate a number of distinct approaches
to the ways in which we come to know our own psychological lives. The first
three weeks (Section I) will focus on knowledge of belief, and the next three
weeks (Section II) will focus on knowledge of action. In both subsections of
the course a perceptual account of our knowledge of our beliefs and actions
will be contrasted with what we might called practical account of self-knowledge.
An inferential model as an alternative to both will also be considered. In the
last week of Section II (on Libet) students will be presented with arguments
from the neuroscience literature that aim to suggest that actions are not in
fact brought about by the decisions or intentions of agents - but are
automatically produced. The conclusiveness of these arguments will be evaluated
and more recent work in neuroscience suggesting hat Libet’s original
conclusions will be reviewed. The final section of the course (Section III)
will be concerned to explore the nature and significance of a different kind of
consciousness we have of ourselves, that is a consciousness mediated by the
consciousness of other people. Interpersonal self-consciousness is a consciousness
of ourselves as the object of consciousness of another. The course will
consider the nature of such consciousness and will argue that it should be play
an important role in our theory of the self-conscious emotions. The emotion of
shame will be a case study. The course will end by considering the ways in
which human beings can induce and escape such interpersonal self-consciousness.
Reduced Syllabus:</p>
<p class="p">Section I</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Self-Knowledge and
Belief – Introduction and Perceptual Models </p>
<p class="p">Key Readings:</p>
<p class="p">David Armstrong, A Materialist Theory of Mind pp.323-7, 333-8.
Chapter VI, ‘Introspection’ of Self-Knowledge, Cassam (ed).</p>
<p class="p">Sydney Shoemaker, The Royce
Lectures: ‘Self-Knowledge and “Inner Sense”’ (I and II) his First Person
Perspective and Other Essays.</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. Self-Knowledge and
Belief – Transparency Models </p>
<p class="p">Moran, R. Authority and
Estrangement, Chapters 3 and 4. </p>
<p class="p">O’Brien, L. ‘Moran on Agency
and Self-Knowledge’, European Journal of Philosophy, 11: 375-390. </p>
<p class="p">Byrne, A (2011) ‘Transparency
and Self-Knowledge - I’ Aristotelian Society, Supplementary Volume, Vol 85.1</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. Self-Knowledge and
Belief – Inferential Models</p>
<p class="p">Ryle, G. The Concept of Mind, p.160-73, 177-89,
Chapter 1. ‘Self-Knowledge’ of Self-Knowledge, Cassam (ed).</p>
<p class="p">Cassam, Q. (2010-11) ‘Knowing
What You Believe’ Aristotelian Society, Proceedings, Vol 111.1</p>
<p class="p">Cassam, Q. Self-Knowledge for
Humans, Chapter 11. </p>
<p class="p">Section II</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Self-knowledge and
Action – Retrospective Models: Observation and Proprioception </p>
<p class="p">O’Brien, L. ‘On Knowing One’s Own Actions’ in Agency and
Self-Awareness (eds) Eilan and Roessler.</p>
<p class="p">Danto, A.C. (1963), ‘What We
Can Do’, Journal of Philosophy LX </p>
<p class="p">Donnellan, K. (1963) ‘Knowing
What I am Doing’ Journal of Philosophy LX </p>
<p class="p">O’Shaughnessy, B. (1963),
‘Observation and the Will’, Journal of Philosophy LX</p>
<p class="p">Marcel, A. “The Sense of
Agency: Awareness and Ownership of Action”, in J. Roessler and N. Eilan (eds.)
Agency and Self-Awareness (2003) (Oxford: Oxford University Press), pp. 48-93.</p>
<p class="p">Haggard, P. ‘Conscious
Awareness of Intention and Action’ in J. Roessler and N. Eilan (eds.) Agency
and Self-Awareness (2003) (Oxford: Oxford University Press), pp. 48-93.</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Self-knowledge and
Action – Prospective Models: Intentions and Tryings </p>
<p class="p">Velleman, J.D. Practical Reflection, Princeton, New Jersey:
Princeton University Press</p>
<p class="p">Dunn, R. (1998) ‘Knowing What I’m About To Do Without
Evidence’, International Journal of Philosophical Studies Vo. 6 (2) 231-252</p>
<p class="p">K Setiya (2008) ‘Practical
Knowledge’, Ethics, Vol 118:3, p.. </p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Self-Knowledge and
Action, Inferential Models and Acting on Reason </p>
<p class="p">Paul, S. “How we know what
we’re doing” Philosophers’ Imprint vol. 9, no. 11, October 2009 </p>
<p class="p">Anscombe, G.E.M. Intention</p>
<p class="p">Anscombe, G. E.M. (1963),
‘Two Kinds of Error in Action’, Journal of Philosophy LX </p>
<p class="p">Week 7. Actions without
agency? Libet </p>
<p class="p">Libet, Benjamin W. (1999). Do
we have free will? Journal of Consciousness Studies 6:47-57.</p>
<p class="p">Wegner, Daniel M. (2003). The
mind’s best trick: how we experience conscious will. Trends in Cognitive
Sciences, Vol. 7, No. 2, pp. 65-69.</p>
<p class="p">Bayne, T. ‘Libet and the Case
for Free Will Scepticism’ in Swinburne,
Richard, editor(s). Free Will and Modern Science. Oxford: Oxford University
Press, pp. 25-46. . Oxford: Oxford University Press; 2011. p. 25-46. Link:
www.philosophy.ox.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/.../free_will_web.pdf</p>
<p class="p">Section III: </p>
<p class="p">Week 8: Interpersonal
Self-Consciousness </p>
<p class="p">L. O’Brien, ‘Ordinary
Self-Consciousness’ in Liu and Perry (eds) Consciousness and the Self. </p>
<p class="p">U. Neisser, (1988) ‘Five
kinds of self-knowledge’. Philosophical Psychology, 1, 35–59.(</p>
<p class="p">C. Peacocke, ‘Interpersonal
Self-Consciousness’, Philosophical Studies (2014) 170: 25-38</p>
<p class="p">M. Lewis, (1991) Ways of
Knowing: Objective self-awareness or consciousness, Developmental Review, 11.3:
231-243.</p>
<p class="p">B. Fredrickson and T. Roberts,
‘Objectification Theory: Towards Understanding Women’s Lived Experiences and
Mental Health’. Psychology of Women Quarterly, 21.2:173-206</p>
<p class="p">Week 9: Self-Conscious
Emotions: Shame and Embarrassment</p>
<p class="p">C. Darwin, The expression of
the emotions in man and animals: Chap. X. (Hatred And Anger); Chap. XI
(Disdain—Contempt—Disgust—Guilt—Pride, Etc.—Helplessness—Patience—Affirmation
And Negation.)</p>
<p class="p">M. Lewis, (1995)
‘Embarrassment: The Emotion of Self-Exposure and Self-Evaluation’ in J.P.
Tangney, J.P. and Fischer, K.W. (eds.) Self-conscious Emotions: the Psychology
of Shame, Guilt, Embarrassment and Pride. (pp.192-218) New York: Guildford
Press. </p>
<p class="p">L. Purshouse, ‘Embarrassment: A Philosophical Analysis’,
Philosophy (2001) 76: 515-540. </p>
<p class="p">G. Taylor, Pride, Shame and
Guilt, Chapter 3</p>
<p class="p">J.D. Velleman, ‘The Genesis
of Shame’ Philosophy and Public Affairs (2001) 30.1: 27-52. </p>
<p class="p">B. Williams, Shame and
Necessity, Chapter IV, ‘Shame and Autonomy’.</p>
<p class="p">Week10: Self-Consciousness:
Inducing and Avoiding</p>
<p class="p">Morgan, D. and O’Brien, L.
(2016) “Getting Out of Your Head: Addiction and the Motive of Self-escape’,
Mind and Language. </p>
<p class="p">J.G. Hull, ‘A self-awareness
model of the causes and effects of alcohol consumption.’ </p>
<p class="p">W. Du Bois, The Souls of
Black Folk, Chapter 1. </p>
<p class="p">J. Stuewig &amp; J. Price
Tangney, ‘Shame and Guilt in Antisocial and Risky Behaviours, in J.L. Tracy,
R.W. Robins &amp; J. Price Tangney (eds.) The Self-Conscious Emotions: Theory
and Research. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA18 Making Sense of the Senses</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Mark Kalderon<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> An introduction to advanced themes in the
philosophy of perception through a comparison of vision, audition, and touch.</p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading: </p>
<p class="p">· CD Broad, “Elementary
Reflections on Sense Perception”</p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p">Week 1. Visuocentrism and the
Metaphysics of Experience</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: CD Broad,
“Elementary Reflections on Sense Perception”, Philosophy, 1952, 27, 100, 3-17;
Richard Sorabji, “Aristotle on Demarcating the Five Senses:, The Philosophical
Review, 1971, 80, 1, 55-79</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Matthew
Nudds, “The Significance of the Senses”, Proceedings of the Aristotelian
Society, 2004, 104, 1, 31-51</p>
<p class="p">Week 2. Color Constancy</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Jonathan
Cohen, &quot;Color Constancy as Counterfactual&quot;, Australasian Journal of
Philosophy, 2008, 86, 1, 61-92; David
Hilbert, &quot;Color Constancy and the Complexity of Color&quot;, Philosophical
Topics, 2005, 33, 1, 141-158</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Dorothea
Jameson and Leo M. Hurvich, &quot;Essay Concerning Color Constancy&quot;,
Annual Review of Psychology, 1989, 40, 1-24</p>
<p class="p">Week 3. The Event of Color?</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Robert
Pasnau, “The Event of Color”, Philosophical Studies, 2009, 142, 3, 353-369</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: CD Broad,
“Elementary Reflections on Sense Perception”, Philosophy, 1952, 27, 100, 3-17</p>
<p class="p">Week 4. Color Enactivism</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Alva Noë,
“Colors Enacted”, chapter 4 of Action and Perception, 2004, MIT Press</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: MGF
Martin, &quot;Commentary on Action and Perception&quot; Philosophy and
Phenomenological Research, 2008, 76:3 674--681</p>
<p class="p">Week 5. Sounds and Events</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Casey
O'Callaghan, &quot;Sounds and Events&quot; in Sounds and Perception, edited by
Casey O'Callaghan and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP; Robert Pasnau, &quot;What is
Sound&quot; Philosophical Quarterly 50:196 309-24 1999 </p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Robert
Pasnau, &quot;Sensible Qualities: The Case of Sound&quot; Journal of the
History of Philosophy 38:1 27-40 2000</p>
<p class="p">Week 6. Sound and Space</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Matthew
Nudds, “Sound and Space”, Sound and Perception, edited by Cassey O’Callaghan
and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP; Roberto Casati and Jerome Dokic, “Some Varieties
of Spatial Hearing” ”, Sound and Perception, edited by Cassey O’Callaghan and
Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Brian
O'Shaughnessy, &quot;The Location of a Perceived Sound&quot; in Sound and
perception, edited by Casey O'Callaghan and Matthew Nudds, 2009, OUP</p>
<p class="p">Week 7. The Sound of Silence</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Roy
Sorenson, &quot;Hearing Silence: The Perception and Introspection of
Absences&quot; in Sound and perception, edited by Casey O'Callaghan and Matthew
Nudds, 2009, OUP; Ian Phillips, &quot;Hearing and Hallucinating Silence&quot;
in Hallucinations edited by Fiona MacPherson MIT Press</p>
<p class="p">· Further Reading: Casey O'Callaghan,
&quot;On Privations and Their Perception&quot;, Acata Anal, 2011, 26 175-186;
Matt Soteriou, &quot;The Perception of Absence, Space, and Time&quot; in
Perception, Causation, and Objectivity, 2011, OUP</p>
<p class="p">Week 8. The Sense of Touch?</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Brian
O'Shaughnessy, &quot;The Sense of Touch&quot; Australasian Journal of
Philosophy, 1989; Matthew Ratcliffe, &quot;What is Touch?&quot;, Australasian
Journal of Philosophy, 2011, 1-20</p>
<p class="p">Week 9. Haptic Touch</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: Matthew
Fulkerson, &quot;The Unity of Haptic Touch&quot;, Philosophical Psychology,
2011, 24, 4, 493 - 516</p>
<p class="p">· Further reading: Susan
Lederman and Roberta L. Klatzky, &quot;Hand Movements: A Window into Haptic
Object Recognition&quot; Cognitive Psychology 19 342-68 1987</p>
<p class="p">Week 10. Sight and Touch</p>
<p class="p">· Required Reading: MGF
Martin, &quot;Sight and Touch&quot; in The Contents of Experience edited by Tim
Crane, 1992, CUP </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA22 The Self in Early Analytic Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Rory Madden</p>
<p class="p">
Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">
Area: C</p>
<p class="p">
Assessment: Essay 4500<br /><br />
Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p">The aim of this graduate
research seminar is to reach an understanding and assessment of some early
analytic writings about the self. Readings may range from late 19th Century
influences such as Brentano and James, through Russell, Wittgenstein, Broad,
and Schlick, and as far as Grice and Strawson in the mid-20th Century.
Background reading: Russell, Bertrand. ‘Knowledge by Acquaintance and Knowledge by Description’ Proceedings of
the Aristotelian Society 1910-11</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA35 20th Century Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Mark Kalderon</p>
<p class="p">
Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">
Area: C</p>
<p class="p">
Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">
Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /></p>
<p class="p">20th Century Philosophy is
dedicated to reading great if neglected texts of the twentieth century. The
text varies year by year. This year we shall be reading Peter Geach’s Mental
Acts. Mental Acts contains, inter alia, an influential critique of behaviourism
and contains as well the kernel of the Frege-Geach objection to experessivism.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA41 Research Seminar: 19th Century Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Tom Stern</p>
<p class="p">
Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">
Area: C</p>
<p class="p">
Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p"><br />
Shared: MPhil Stud</p>
<p class="p">Description: </p>
<p class="p">This module is a research
seminar in 19th century philosophy. Subject matter can vary year by year, but
might include: the philosophy of Nietzsche, Hegel, Schopenhauer and related
figures in the history of philosophy. In 2017/18, the focus of the class will
be on Hegel's account of 'self-consciousness' in his Phenomenology of Spirit.
This includes his account of recognition and the famous 'master-slave
dialectic'.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA47 Perception and Its Objects</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Mark Kalderon</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Area: A</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">This course is intended to
take students through key recent contributions within the Philosophy of
Perception or the Metaphysics of Sensibilia (such as colour or sound). This
year we shall be reading Mazvitta Chirimuuta’s Outside Color. All members of
the class are required to prepare the reading each week. One student each week
will be responsible for giving a short presentation on the work, and the class
as a whole will then discuss any issues raised.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA57 Philosophy Politics &amp; Economics of Health</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: James Wilson</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">This module examines some
central ethical ethical, economic and political problems facing health policy
in the UK and abroad, especially in relation to social justice. Topics covered
include: how to allocate healthcare resources (e.g. should the NHS cover all
new drug treatments, regardless of how expensive they are? Who should decide?);
the appropriate role of the state in protecting and promoting health (e.g.
should smoking be banned?); when inequalities in health and life expectancy are
unfair; and special challenges posed by infectious diseases.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA58 Metaphysics of Science</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Luke
Fenton-Glynn</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Area: A</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">In this module, we will cover
three central topics in the metaphysics of science: causation, chance and the
laws of nature. Questions to be addressed include: What are laws of nature? Are
there laws other than those described by physics (for instance, are there laws
of biology or economics)? What is probability? Are there objective probabilities
(chances) in the world? How do chances relate to laws? What is causation? How
does causation relate to chance? No background in science or probability theory
is needed for this course.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Recommended general
background reading:</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Fenton-Glynn, L. (2015): ‘A
Simple Introduction to Probability’ &lt;
https://www.academia.edu/12094718/A_Simple_Introduction_to_Probability&gt;.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Paul, L. A. and Hall, N.
(2013): Causation: A User’s Guide (Oxford: OUP)</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Armstrong, D. (1983): What
is a Law of Nature? (Cambridge: CUP).</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Psillos, S. (2002):
Causation and Explanation (Montreal: McGill-Queen’s University Press).</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Hájek, Alan (2012):
‘Interpretations of Probability’, The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Woodward, J. (2005): Making
Things Happen (Oxford: OUP)</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Provisional syllabus</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 1. Causation,
Regularities, and Counterfactuals</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Mackie, J. (1965): 'Causes
and Conditions', American Philosophical Quarterly, Vol. 2, pp. 245-264.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. ‘Causation’,
Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 70, pp. 556-557.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, David (1986):
'Postscripts to &quot;Causation&quot;'. In his Philosophical Papers, Vol. II
(New York: OUP), pp. 172-213. Postscript E: 'Redundant Causation'.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. ‘Causation as
Influence’, in J. Collins, N. Hall, and L. A. Paul (eds.): Causation and
Counterfactuals (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press), pp. 76-106.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 2. Causation and
Structural Equations</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Hitchcock, C. (2001): ‘The
Intransitivity of Causation Revealed in Equations and Graphs’, Journal of
Philosophy, Vol. 98, pp. 273-299.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 3. Causation and
Probability</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Hitchcock, C. (2004): ‘Do
All and Only Causes Raise the Probability of Effects?’, in J. Collins, N. Hall,
and L.A. Paul (eds): Causation and Counterfactuals (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press).</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 4. Causation,
Probability, and Causal Models</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Hitchcock, C. (2001): ‘A
Tale of Two Effects’, Philosophical Review, Vol. 110, pp. 361-396.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 5. Interpretations of
Probability</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Hájek, Alan (2012):
&quot;Interpretations of Probability&quot;, The Stanford Encyclopedia of
Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 6. Problems with the
Naïve Regularity Theory of Laws</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Armstrong, D. (1983): What
is a Law of Nature? (Cambridge: CUP), pp. 11-59.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 7. The Best System
Analysis of Laws and Chance</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Lewis, D. (1994): ‘Humean
Supervenience Debugged’, Mind, Vol. 103, Sections 2-4 only.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 8. Special Sciences</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Oppenheim, P. and Putnam,
H. (1958): 'Unity of Science as a Working Hypothesis', , in H. Feigl et al.,
eds., Minnesota Studies in the Philosophy of Science, vol. 2 (Minneapolis:
Minnesota University Press), pp. 3-36.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Fodor, J. (1974): ‘Special
Sciences (Or: The Disunity of Science as a Working Hypothesis)’, Synthese, Vol.
28, pp. 97-115.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 9. Invariant
Generalisations</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Woodward, J. and Hitchcock,
C. (2003): ‘Explanatory Generalizations, Part I: A Counterfactual Account’,
Noûs, Vol. 37, pp. 1-24.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Topic 10. Special Sciences,
Statistical Mechanics, &amp; The Direction of Time</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Loewer, B. (2012): 'Two
Accounts of Laws and Time', Philosophical Studies, Vol. 160, pp. 115-137.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Loewer, B. (2012): 'The
Emergence of Time's Arrows and Special Science Laws From Physics', Interface
Focus, Vol. 2, pp. 13-19.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">Sample questions:</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Are laws of nature mere
regularities?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Are the generalisations of
the special sciences (e.g. biology, chemistry, economics) genuine laws of nature?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Are the special sciences
reducible to physics?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Is all probability
subjective, or are there objective probabilities in the world?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Can causation be understood
in terms of probabilistic relations between events?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Can structural equations
approaches to causation help us overcome the difficulties facing more
traditional philosophical accounts of causation?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">• Can the direction of
causation and the direction of time be reduced to the direction of entropy
increase?</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">No background in science or
probability theory is needed for this course.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA65 Special Topics in Ancient Philosophy A</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: David Sedley<br />Term: Fortnightly across terms 1 and 2
<br />Area: C
<br />Assessment: Essay 4500 words
<br />Shared: MPhil Stud</p>
<p class="p">Description: This course will discuss a topic of philosophical significance in the field of ancient philosophy, as presented by the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/keeling/index_right">Keeling Scholar in Ancient Philosophy</a>, in their first year of tenure. The course may focus on a particular text, such as a Platonic dialogue, an Aristotelian treatise, or a set of thematically unified fragments from a Pre-Socratic philosopher or Hellenistic philosopher or school. Alternatively, it may discuss a topic or interconnected set of issues that is treated over a number of ancient texts, such as for example ‘self-knowledge in classical philosophical thought’, or ‘the relation between form, universal and essence in Aristotle’, or ‘virtue ethics in Plato’s middle and late dialogues’.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA70 Research Seminar in Legal Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Amanda Greene</p>
<p class="p">Term: 3 </p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4,500 words
(76%) Written commentary and oral presentation on reading (500 words -
12%) Peer review of commentary (12%)</p>
<p class="p">Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">This module focuses on key
topics in legal philosophy. It is intended for postgraduate students who have
had prior experience in moral or political philosophy. Topics will vary by
year, but may include obligation to obey the law, legal interpretation,
constitutional theory, punishment, authority, etc.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA73 Research Seminar: Recent Work in Political Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Han van
Wietmarschen</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Readings will be based on
important books or papers published in the last few years. Students will be
expected to read one or more chapters or papers each week, and come to the
class ready to lead or contribute to discussion of the work set. Students will
be examined by means of an essay on one or more of the topics covered in the
class.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA76 Research Seminar in Intentional Agency, Acting for a Reason and Responsibility</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ulrike Heuer</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500 words</p>
<p class="p">Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">The module explores theories
of responsibility in attempting to account for the grounds and the limits of
what we are responsible for. In doing so the module will examine distinct
conceptions of responsibility and some fundamental challenges that arise in
relation to it (e.g. whether responsibility is an incoherent concept, or
whether there is ‘moral luck’). In light of these general considerations the
module will then aim to explore related topics, such as blameworthiness,
excuses and collective responsibility. The fundamental aim is to understand the
nature of responsibility, and the resources contemporary theoretic approaches
may (or may not) have in attempting to account for our ways of ascribing
actions to ourselves and others, and judging them.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA88 Feminism and Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Amia
Srinivasan<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> This course will be an advanced introduction to
the philosophical issues raised and addressed by the ongoing fight for women's
liberation from patriarchal oppression. Topics include: the metaphysics of
gender, intersectionality, feminism and trans issues, feminist epistemology,
pornography, sex and sexual 'liberation', feminist critiques of liberalism and
capitalism, and the relationship between feminism and philosophy. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA90 Graduate Studies in Ethics and Political Philosophy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Véronique
Munoz-Dardé<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> The course aims to provide graduate Philosophy
students with an understanding of some central themes, theories and arguments
in ethics, society and political philosophy. </p>
<p class="p">The topic for 2017/18 is Contractualism and its Critics.</p>
<p class="p">This seminar will be organized around contractualist approaches in contemporary political philosophy. The seminar will pursue three key themes. First, authority: Is the principal concern of political theory the authority of the state and the source of our obligations to obey state institutions and its agents? If not, what should our principal concerns in political philosophy be? Second, the weight of numbers: Aren’t aggregative concerns intuitively compelling in certain social policy contexts? Does that show that we must move beyond a pure individualistic perspective to one in which consequential outcomes are part of the measure of justice? Third, equality: Is equality or fairness a political value in itself? In what sense can a position claim to be egalitarian or guided by equality if it denies that equality has a special value?</p>
<p class="p">In pursuing these questions, we will consider writings by T. M. Scanlon, John Rawls, Joseph Raz and G. A. Cohen, as well as some historical texts from Jean-Jacques Rousseau and David Hume.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA91 Formal Epistemology</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Luke
Fenton-Glynn</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: A</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: 2 Sets of
exercises (15% each) and 1 essay (2500 wds - 70%)</p>
<p class="p">Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Students will be introduced
to the topic of formal epistemology. This will involve teaching the basic
principles of probability theory, the arguments that have been given that a
rational agent’s degrees of belief are represented by a probability function,
and the arguments for and against principles that have been proposed concerning
how a rational agent’s degrees of belief are constrained (both synchronically
and in their evolution over time). Expected Utility Theory will also be
introduced, and critically evaluated, as the orthodox decision theory for
agents with probabilistic degrees of belief.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA93 Graduate Studies in Philosophy of Action</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Douglas Lavin</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Area: B</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4500</p>
<p class="p">Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">This is a graduate level
study of contemporary work in the philosophy of action. Topics include: the
nature and explanation of action, temporality of action, practical knowledge,
skill and practical reasoning. Various
authors considered with special attention to G. E. M. Anscombe and Donald
Davidson.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA95 Recent Work in Practical Philosophy</a></dt>

     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Douglas Lavin<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> A graduate level study of some important recent
work in practical philosophy. <br /></p>
<p class="p">For more information please email <a href="mailto:d.lavin@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">d.lavin@ucl.ac.uk</a></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA97 Topics in Moral Psychology</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Douglas Lavin<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: <br /> Investigation of a familiar and puzzling
elements of moral life, e.g., promising, forgiveness, authority, pride/shame,
pleasure, respect/humiliation, self-control, love and friendship, competitiveness. Topics and texts may differ year to year. <br /></p>
<p class="p">For more information please email <a href="mailto:d.lavin@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">d.lavin@ucl.ac.uk</a></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGA98 Linguistic semantics and the philosophy of language</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Module Leader: Ethan Nowak</p>
<p class="p">Term: 2</p>
<p class="p">Area: A</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 3000 words
(70%) and problem sets (30%)</p>
<p class="p">Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">This module introduces the
technical machinery of contemporary linguistic semantics, and explores the
philosophical foundations and applications of the same. The module begins with
an exploration of the significance of two ideas: a.) that knowing the truth
conditions associated with an assertoric sentence is knowing its meaning and
b.) that a theory of meaning for natural language must be compositional. The
rest of the module is devoted to the construction of a formal theory that
combines those ideas with the Fregean principle of type-driven interpretation
to explain the behavior of simple sentences, relative clauses, quantificational
constructions, demonstratives, and other philosophically-interesting expression
types. Significant familiarity with formal methods is presupposed. Students who
do not have experience with intermediate or advanced logic should consult the
instructor before registering for this module.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGAA1 Research Seminar: Aggregation in Ethics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Joe Horton<br />
Term: 2<br />
Area: B<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500 words <br />
Shared: MPhil</p>
<p class="p"> Description: Is there any number of people you should save from paralysis rather than saving one person from death? Is there any number of people you should save from a headache rather than saving one person from death? Many people answer these questions ‘yes’ and ‘no’ respectively. In this course, we will consider whether this position can be defended, by evaluating recent work on aggregation in ethics.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGAA2 The Philosophical Foundations of Effective Altruism</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Joe Horton<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: B
<br />Assessment: Essay 4500 words<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: Effective Altruism is a relatively new social movement, but it has already had a significant impact. Its primary aim is to encourage people to use evidence and careful reasoning to do the most good possible with their charitable donations. An important secondary aim is to encourage people to give more to the most effective charities. In this course, we will consider a variety of philosophical questions and controversies surrounding the Effective Altruism movement. These questions include:</p>
<p class="p">Should we be Effective Altruists?</p>
<p class="p">What justifies Effective Altruism? — Must Effective Altruists be Utilitarians or Consequentialists, or can they also be Non-Consequentialists?</p>
<p class="p">What charitable causes do the most good?</p>
<p class="p">Should we buy products made in sweatshops?</p>
<p class="p">Should we care about human suffering more than animal suffering?</p>
<p class="p">Which matters more: ending poverty or controlling artificial intelligence?</p>
<p class="p">Should we prioritise preventing the suffering of people who are alive now over preventing the suffering of future generations?</p>
<p class="p">Does the threat of future human extinction matter for us here and now?</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGAA3 Free Speech and Theories of Autonomy</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Robert Simpson<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: B
<br />Assessment: Essay 4500 words<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: In this module we will examine the various conceptions of ‘autonomy’ that have been appealed to by philosophers and legal theorists as part of a defense of free speech principles. We will also survey some influential conceptions of autonomy that have been espoused by moral philosophers. Our overarching aim will be to consider how successful an autonomy-based defense of free speech is, or could be, and what the most persuasive or promising form of such a defense might involve.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGAA4 Metaethics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Mat Simpson<br />Term: 2
<br />Area: B
<br />Assessment: Essay 4500 words<br />Shared: BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p">Description: Metaethics involves questions about the nature of value and of ethical thought and language. In this course students will learn about four prominent metaethical theories – naturalism, non-naturalism, constructivism, and expressivism. They will then study four recent debates which each have interesting connections with other areas of philosophy – the question of whether moral judgements motivate, the evolutionary debunking of morality, moral testimony and disagreement, and the problem of creeping minimalism.</p>
<p class="p">Text include:</p>
<p class="p">Geoffrey Sayre-McCord, ed. Essays on Moral Realism Cornell University Press 1988</p>
<p class="p">Copp, David, ed. The Oxford Handbook of Ethical Theory. Oxford University Press, 2007.</p>
<p class="p">LaFollette, Hugh, ed. The Blackwell Guide to Ethical Theory. Oxford: Blackwell, 2000.</p>
<p class="p">Simon Blackburn, Ruling Passions (Oxford University Press 1998)</p>
<p class="p">Russ Shafer-Landu, ed. Oxford Studies in Metaethics (several volumes available, all contain relevant material.)</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PHILGAA5 Representation and Reality</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: Mat Simpson<br />
Term: 1<br />
Area: A<br />
Assessment: Essay 4500 words<br />
Shared:BA \ MPhil</p>
<p class="p"> Description: In this module we will investigate the relationship between the world and our representation of it by our language and thoughts. We will study a number of philosophical debates from the last century, which all center on the idea that our theories about human language and thought will in some way affect what we think about reality. Topics studied will include reference and non-existence objects, modality and causation, pragmatism about truth, non-representational theories of meaning and anti-metaphysical arguments. Text include:</p>
<p class="p">- Ian Hacking, 1975, Why Does Language Matter to Philosophy? (Cambridge University Press)</p>
<p class="p">- Amie Thomasson, 2015, Ontology Made Easy (Oxford University Press)</p>
<p class="p">- Steven Gross, Nicholas Tebbe and Michael Williams, eds., 2015, Meaning without Representation (Oxford University Press)</p>
<p class="p">- Huw Price, ed., 2013 Expressivism, Pragmatism and Representationalism, (Cambridge University Press)</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HHUMG003 Illness</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Module Leader: James Wilson</p>
<p class="p">Term: 1</p>
<p class="p">Assessment: Essay 4000</p>
<p class="p">This interdisciplinary module explores the experience of illness. It focuses in particular on tensions between subjective and objective, examining how rich and socially embedded interpretive responses to the experience of illness, can and should be brought into dialogue with biomedical, philosophical, and sociological understandings of the same phenomena.</p>
<p class="p">The first half of the course focuses on the role of narrative in constituting selves and illness experiences. We examine some ways in which those living with illness construct narratives to give expression to their experiences, and what a focus experience and narratives adds to a more biomedical conception of illness. The second half focuses on the intersection between biology, power and culture in constructing responses to illness, examining ideas of care and suffering, disability, stigma, illness experiences that struggle to receive recognition from biomedical science, and living under genetic risk.  </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>


<table class="silvatable plain" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/docs/ma-grad-mods.pdf" target="_blank">MA Dedicated Graduate Modules </a>
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/docs/ma-term-1.pdf" target="_blank">Term 1 Timetable</a>
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/docs/ma-term-2.pdf" target="_blank">Term 2 Timetable</a>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

        <ul class="breadcrumb__list">
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk">UCL Home</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Research Programmes</h1>
<ul class="disc">
<li>This <a href="https://moodle.ucl.ac.uk/mod/book/view.php?id=1628389" target="_blank">guide in Moodle</a> contains all the essential information for research students in the Philosophy Department.
</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/research-programmes/mphil-modules" target="_self">MPhil Stud modules</a>: List of all modules with brief description.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/research-programmes/key-contacts" target="_self">Key Contacts</a>: Who to get in touch with for various enquiries.</li>
<li>Timetable for MPhil Stud modules</li>
</ul>






<div id="accordion">

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">MPhil Stud Second Year Students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<table class="silvatable plain" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="66%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Chandler Clarke
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  I am primarily interested in issues in Ancient (Plato, Aristotle) and Hellenistic Philosophy (Epictetus) in particular with topics involving the Metaphysics of Causation and Teleology. However, I am also deeply interested in Medieval Philosophy (Aquinas, Occam, Al-Ghazali ) and contemporary Philosophy of Religion and Metaphysics
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Nicholas Currie 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  Interests: Transcendental idealism (and Kantian philosophy more generally), absolute idealism, normativity and truth, pragmatism, the later philosophy of Ludwig Wittgenstein, Wilfrid Sellars and the Pittsburgh school, 20th century anti-realism (i.e., Dummett, Putnam), Scottish common-sense philosophy, Aristotle (in particular the Organon), intersubjectivity and moral reasoning, aesthetics.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Jessica Fischer
