<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PhD Students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<table class="silvatable list" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="66%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Contact A-Z</strong>
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Research</strong>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Showkat Ali 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Moral and Political Philosophy
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Julian Bacharach
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">My
main area of research is in the metaphysics of mind and action, with a
particular focus on the temporal aspects of rational human agency. I also have
interests in the foundations of value, and in Kant, Frege, and Wittgenstein.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Akosua Bonsu
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of psychiatry, the self,
  the emotions, history of philosophy &amp; Phenomenology </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current:</strong> My PhD thesis proposes a particular
  relationship between shame and the self, and in light of this, argues for a
  particular interpretation of bodily shame. </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  James Brown 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Metaethics (especially expressivism); Philosophy of Language;
Metaphysics.
<a href="http://ucl.academia.edu/JamesBrown" target="_blank"><strong>(academia.edu profile)</strong></a> 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Luke Burke
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Interests</strong>: formal semantics, logic, philosophy
of language and of linguistics, the ontology of musical works </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Hannah Carnegy-Arbuthnott
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Political and moral philosophy,
  philosophy of mind, philosophy of art.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Vanessa Carr 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Metaphysics, Philosophy of Mind,
  Philosophy of Action, Philosophy of Science, and Psychology.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Tony Cheng<br /><br />
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of Perception and Psychology; Metaphysics
and Epistemology</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current:</strong> In the past few years I have been focusing on the
relation between visual attention and consciousness. Now in the
PhD dissertation Sense, Space, and Self, I seek to argue
that the first-person is in many ways implicated in sense perception and bodily
awareness. I am also interested in various areas in psychology, such as
attention, cross-modal effects, and cognitive development. I have been doing
joint works with Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UCL, and Institute of
Philosophy, University of London.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Web:</strong><a href="http://philpapers.org/s/tony%20cheng" target="_blank"> http://philpapers.org/s/tony%20cheng</a></p>
<p class="p"> </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Niels Christensen <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Emily Crampton<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Ancient Philosophy, especially
  Aristotle's metaphysics. I also have an interest in so
  called 'existentialist' ontologies, especially those of Sartre and
  Kierkegaard.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current: </strong>I am currently working on the role
  played by the 'active intellect', elsewhere termed 'the unmoved mover'
  or 'god', in Aristotle's metaphysics.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Kathrine Cucurru <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests</strong>: Early Modern Philosophy,
Aesthetics, Hume, Kant, philosophical practice.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current research</strong>: Early eighteenth-century
British conceptions of the sublime. My PhD explores the psychological, moral,
and metaphysical commitments of accounts prior to Edmund Burke,
particularly John Dennis and Shaftesbury. It expands on and
challenges aspects of the existing view of the sublime in the history of
aesthetics.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Blog</strong>: <a href="https://howtobeaphilosopher.wordpress.com/" target="_blank">howtobeaphilosopher.wordpress.com</a></p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Catherine Dale 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Metaphysics, Philosophy of Language, Feminist Philosophy, (Later)
Wittgenstein, and Early Modern Philosophy.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Jack Davis <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of Language, Aesthetics,
  Philosophy of Mind and Psychology.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current research</strong>: My PhD considers the cognitive underpinnings of
the propositional imagination and looks at how the propositional imagination
features in debates in aesthetics and philosophy of mind and psychology.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Taylor Enoch 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Aesthetics, philosophy of art, and neuroaesthetics;
interdisciplinary philosophy of psychology, esp. Gestaltism; metaphilosophy and
experimental philosophy; phenomenology, existentialism, and absurdism.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current: </strong>Generally, my work focuses on methodology and
interdisciplinarity in philosophical aesthetics. My MPhil thesis concerns the
Analytic Aestheticians of the mid-20C and their attempted methodological shift,
especially for the notions of analyticity and systematicity. My PhD thesis
shall sketch what I call a 'methodologically prior' aesthetics. </p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Website:</strong>
 <a href="http://taylorinlondon.wix.com/taylordenoch" target="_self">http://taylorinlondon.wix.com/taylordenoch</a> </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Benjamin Fardell<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong><strong> </strong>Ethics,
Value theory, Practical reason, Political philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">I’m
currently interested in what it could mean for something to be ‘priceless’. In
the face of the highly influential aggregative picture of individual practical
reasoning, this is hard. Importantly, the issue affects how we conceive of
well-being, which I believe must import qualitative and not just quantitative
distinctions in value. These might be expressed in terms of some notion of
need, as opposed to what is unnecessary.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Peter Faulconbridge<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of Mind, Philosophy of
  Psychology, Philosophy of Psychiatry, Wittgenstein, Aesthetics.<br /> <strong>Current:</strong> I am currently looking at the relations between content,
  belief and rationality, in particular as they figure in the philosophical and
  psychiatric literature on delusion. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Miguel Ferreira Dos Santos <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophical Methodology,
  Metaphysics, Aesthetics, Philosophy of Mind, and Ethics. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Lisa Grant<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Daniel Guillery<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Political and Moral Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current:</strong> Issues of state legitimacy, state
  coercion, anarchism and the relation of these to questions of feasibility. I
  have also done work on the concept of feasibility generally and its role in
  political and moral philosophy and intend to continue this and incorporate it
  into the above.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Margaret Hampson<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Ancient Philosophy, in particular
  Ethics &amp; Moral Psychology in Aristotle and Hellenistic Schools; History
  of Philosophy; Philosophy of Emotion.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Alec Hinshelwood<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of action, philosophy of
  mind, ethics, Kant, Nietzsche, Aristotle, Marx, psychoanalysis.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Charles Jansen
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">My
research aims to demonstrate how an account of persons as animals might
helpfully contribute to other debates in which an account of personhood
might be expected to play a key theoretical role (e.g. in value theory and the
philosophy of mind). I'm currently looking into the role that an account of
animal nature might play in the interpretation and evaluation of other
people's evaluative perspectives, and into related ideas concerning a
distinctively human second nature/ethical upbringing.'</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Andrew Knox 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Political Philosophy, Ethics,
  Metaethics, Philosophy of History.<br /> <br /> <strong>Current:</strong> The relationship between ethical and political
  philosophy and the possibility of political philosophy that does not rely on
  of moral premises. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  James Laing 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> philosophy of mind, metaphysics and ethics. My
MPhil Thesis was on the experience of time.  <br /><a href="https://ucl.academia.edu/JamesLaing" target="_blank"><strong>(academia.edu profile)</strong></a>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Michael Markunas 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Metaphysics, Philosophy of Mind, Philosophy of Perception and Neuroscience. Also interested in Nietzsche and Wittgenstein.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Rowan Mellor 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  I am currently working on a
study of collective responsibility. Recently, important philosophical work has
been conducted on both individual moral responsibility and the logic and
metaphysics of plurals. My research attempts to bring this work together to
provide a novel account of collective responsibility: moral responsibility for
an action/outcome which is ascribed to a plurality of agents, rather than a
single agent. I believe that this account can help resolve problem cases in
which something morally wrong appears to have been done, but where it seems
inappropriate to criticise individuals for their actions. Such cases seem
prevalent in the modern world e.g. climate change, consumer patterns which
perpetuate unacceptable working conditions etc. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Polly Mitchell <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Moral and political philosophy,
  bioethics, public policy.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Charlie Neil<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Epistemology.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Barbara Nunez De Caceres Gonzalez
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  David Olbrich
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Ethics, Normativity, Philosophy of Mind, Philosophy of
Action.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current Research</strong>: I'm looking at what makes the moral 'must'
distinctive, and in light of this, what has to be true if we are to be subject
to moral obligations at all.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Edgar Phillips
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of mind and psychology, philosophy of action,
epistemology.
 
 <strong>Current:</strong> Rationality and irrationality; theories of rationality and irrationality
in philosophy and psychology; values, ways of thinking and ‘rationalising’
explanation; intersubjective understanding and ‘the agent's point of view’.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Rory Phillips 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Kant, Fichte, Later modern philosophy, General
philosophy of science, philosophy of biology, philosophy of mind, epistemology,
metaethics and metaphilosophy.  
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Helen Robertson <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Kant, History of Modern Philosophy,
  Metaphysics.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Joshua Rowlands<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Kant, History of Modern Philosophy,
  Metaphysics.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Penelope Rowlatt<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of Mind, Political
  Philosophy
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Josephine Salverda<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of Mathematics,
  Epistemology and Philosophy of Science.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current research:</strong> I am working towards an
  account of explanation in mathematics.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Ashley Shaw<br /><br />
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Philosophy of Mind and Philosophy of Language</strong>: I am interested in the content, ascription and
epistemology of neglected psychological attitudes (e.g. non-representational
attitudes like desire, non-propositional attitudes, de se attitudes). My
research has led me to think about interrogatives and imperatives in natural
language. I am also interested in how these attitudes interact, the nature of
attitudinal conflict or inconsistency, and associated issues like Moore’s
Paradox.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Laura Silva
</td>
<td class="align-left">
   
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Winnie Sung
</td>
<td class="align-left">
   
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Shunichi Takagi  
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Jonas Vandieken<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Moral and Political Philosophy with
  special focus on contractualist theories developed by Rawls and Scanlon,
  History of Philosophy, Epistemology, Bioethics. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Tom Williams<br /> <br /> 
</td>

  <strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of mind and language,
  epistemology, perception, reference.
</td>

                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: []//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';
            }
        </script>

        <script src='//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/main.js'></script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Research Programmes</h1>
<ul class="disc">
<li>This <a href="https://moodle.ucl.ac.uk/mod/book/view.php?id=1628389" target="_blank">guide in Moodle</a> contains all the essential information for research students in the Philosophy Department.
</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/research-programmes/mphil-modules" target="_self">MPhil Stud modules</a>: List of all modules with brief description.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/research-programmes/key-contacts" target="_self">Key Contacts</a>: Who to get in touch with for various enquiries.</li>
<li>Timetable for MPhil Stud modules</li>
</ul>






<div id="accordion">

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">MPhil Stud Second Year Students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<table class="silvatable plain" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="66%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Chandler Clarke
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  I am primarily interested in issues in Ancient (Plato, Aristotle) and Hellenistic Philosophy (Epictetus) in particular with topics involving the Metaphysics of Causation and Teleology. However, I am also deeply interested in Medieval Philosophy (Aquinas, Occam, Al-Ghazali ) and contemporary Philosophy of Religion and Metaphysics
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Nicholas Currie 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  Interests: Transcendental idealism (and Kantian philosophy more generally), absolute idealism, normativity and truth, pragmatism, the later philosophy of Ludwig Wittgenstein, Wilfrid Sellars and the Pittsburgh school, 20th century anti-realism (i.e., Dummett, Putnam), Scottish common-sense philosophy, Aristotle (in particular the Organon), intersubjectivity and moral reasoning, aesthetics.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Jessica Fischer 
</td>
<td class="align-left">

</td>

</td>

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">PhD Students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<table class="silvatable list" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />

<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Contact A-Z</strong>
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Research</strong>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Showkat Ali 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Moral and Political Philosophy
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Julian Bacharach
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">My
main area of research is in the metaphysics of mind and action, with a
particular focus on the temporal aspects of rational human agency. I also have
interests in the foundations of value, and in Kant, Frege, and Wittgenstein.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Akosua Bonsu
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of psychiatry, the self,
  the emotions, history of philosophy &amp; Phenomenology </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current:</strong> My PhD thesis proposes a particular
  relationship between shame and the self, and in light of this, argues for a
  particular interpretation of bodily shame. </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  James Brown 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Metaethics (especially expressivism); Philosophy of Language;
Metaphysics.
<a href="http://ucl.academia.edu/JamesBrown" target="_blank"><strong>(academia.edu profile)</strong></a> 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Luke Burke
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Interests</strong>: formal semantics, logic, philosophy
of language and of linguistics, the ontology of musical works </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Hannah Carnegy-Arbuthnott
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Political and moral philosophy,
  philosophy of mind, philosophy of art.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Vanessa Carr 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Metaphysics, Philosophy of Mind,
  Philosophy of Action, Philosophy of Science, and Psychology.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Tony Cheng<br /><br />
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of Perception and Psychology; Metaphysics
and Epistemology</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current:</strong> In the past few years I have been focusing on the
relation between visual attention and consciousness. Now in the
PhD dissertation Sense, Space, and Self, I seek to argue
that the first-person is in many ways implicated in sense perception and bodily
awareness. I am also interested in various areas in psychology, such as
attention, cross-modal effects, and cognitive development. I have been doing
joint works with Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UCL, and Institute of
Philosophy, University of London.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Web:</strong><a href="http://philpapers.org/s/tony%20cheng" target="_blank"> http://philpapers.org/s/tony%20cheng</a></p>
<p class="p"> </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Niels Christensen <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Emily Crampton<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Ancient Philosophy, especially
  Aristotle's metaphysics. I also have an interest in so
  called 'existentialist' ontologies, especially those of Sartre and
  Kierkegaard.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current: </strong>I am currently working on the role
  played by the 'active intellect', elsewhere termed 'the unmoved mover'
  or 'god', in Aristotle's metaphysics.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Kathrine Cucurru <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests</strong>: Early Modern Philosophy,
Aesthetics, Hume, Kant, philosophical practice.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current research</strong>: Early eighteenth-century
British conceptions of the sublime. My PhD explores the psychological, moral,
and metaphysical commitments of accounts prior to Edmund Burke,
particularly John Dennis and Shaftesbury. It expands on and
challenges aspects of the existing view of the sublime in the history of
aesthetics.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Blog</strong>: <a href="https://howtobeaphilosopher.wordpress.com/" target="_blank">howtobeaphilosopher.wordpress.com</a></p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Catherine Dale 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Metaphysics, Philosophy of Language, Feminist Philosophy, (Later)
Wittgenstein, and Early Modern Philosophy.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Jack Davis <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of Language, Aesthetics,
  Philosophy of Mind and Psychology.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current research</strong>: My PhD considers the cognitive underpinnings of
the propositional imagination and looks at how the propositional imagination
features in debates in aesthetics and philosophy of mind and psychology.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Taylor Enoch 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Aesthetics, philosophy of art, and neuroaesthetics;
interdisciplinary philosophy of psychology, esp. Gestaltism; metaphilosophy and
experimental philosophy; phenomenology, existentialism, and absurdism.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current: </strong>Generally, my work focuses on methodology and
interdisciplinarity in philosophical aesthetics. My MPhil thesis concerns the
Analytic Aestheticians of the mid-20C and their attempted methodological shift,
especially for the notions of analyticity and systematicity. My PhD thesis
shall sketch what I call a 'methodologically prior' aesthetics. </p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Website:</strong>
 <a href="http://taylorinlondon.wix.com/taylordenoch" target="_self">http://taylorinlondon.wix.com/taylordenoch</a> </p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Benjamin Fardell<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong><strong> </strong>Ethics,
Value theory, Practical reason, Political philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p">I’m
currently interested in what it could mean for something to be ‘priceless’. In
the face of the highly influential aggregative picture of individual practical
reasoning, this is hard. Importantly, the issue affects how we conceive of
well-being, which I believe must import qualitative and not just quantitative
distinctions in value. These might be expressed in terms of some notion of
need, as opposed to what is unnecessary.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Peter Faulconbridge<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of Mind, Philosophy of
  Psychology, Philosophy of Psychiatry, Wittgenstein, Aesthetics.<br /> <strong>Current:</strong> I am currently looking at the relations between content,
  belief and rationality, in particular as they figure in the philosophical and
  psychiatric literature on delusion. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Miguel Ferreira Dos Santos <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophical Methodology,
  Metaphysics, Aesthetics, Philosophy of Mind, and Ethics. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Lisa Grant<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Daniel Guillery<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Political and Moral Philosophy.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current:</strong> Issues of state legitimacy, state
  coercion, anarchism and the relation of these to questions of feasibility. I
  have also done work on the concept of feasibility generally and its role in
  political and moral philosophy and intend to continue this and incorporate it
  into the above.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Margaret Hampson<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Ancient Philosophy, in particular
  Ethics &amp; Moral Psychology in Aristotle and Hellenistic Schools; History
  of Philosophy; Philosophy of Emotion.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Alec Hinshelwood<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of action, philosophy of
  mind, ethics, Kant, Nietzsche, Aristotle, Marx, psychoanalysis.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Charles Jansen
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">My
research aims to demonstrate how an account of persons as animals might
helpfully contribute to other debates in which an account of personhood
might be expected to play a key theoretical role (e.g. in value theory and the
philosophy of mind). I'm currently looking into the role that an account of
animal nature might play in the interpretation and evaluation of other
people's evaluative perspectives, and into related ideas concerning a
distinctively human second nature/ethical upbringing.'</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Andrew Knox 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Political Philosophy, Ethics,
  Metaethics, Philosophy of History.<br /> <br /> <strong>Current:</strong> The relationship between ethical and political
  philosophy and the possibility of political philosophy that does not rely on
  of moral premises. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  James Laing 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> philosophy of mind, metaphysics and ethics. My
MPhil Thesis was on the experience of time.  <br /><a href="https://ucl.academia.edu/JamesLaing" target="_blank"><strong>(academia.edu profile)</strong></a>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Michael Markunas 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Metaphysics, Philosophy of Mind, Philosophy of Perception and Neuroscience. Also interested in Nietzsche and Wittgenstein.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Rowan Mellor 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  I am currently working on a
study of collective responsibility. Recently, important philosophical work has
been conducted on both individual moral responsibility and the logic and
metaphysics of plurals. My research attempts to bring this work together to
provide a novel account of collective responsibility: moral responsibility for
an action/outcome which is ascribed to a plurality of agents, rather than a
single agent. I believe that this account can help resolve problem cases in
which something morally wrong appears to have been done, but where it seems
inappropriate to criticise individuals for their actions. Such cases seem
prevalent in the modern world e.g. climate change, consumer patterns which
perpetuate unacceptable working conditions etc. 
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Polly Mitchell <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Moral and political philosophy,
  bioethics, public policy.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Charlie Neil<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests:</strong> Epistemology.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Barbara Nunez De Caceres Gonzalez
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  David Olbrich
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Ethics, Normativity, Philosophy of Mind, Philosophy of
Action.</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current Research</strong>: I'm looking at what makes the moral 'must'
distinctive, and in light of this, what has to be true if we are to be subject
to moral obligations at all.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Edgar Phillips
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Interests:</strong> Philosophy of mind and psychology, philosophy of action,
epistemology.
 
 <strong>Current:</strong> Rationality and irrationality; theories of rationality and irrationality
in philosophy and psychology; values, ways of thinking and ‘rationalising’
explanation; intersubjective understanding and ‘the agent's point of view’.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Rory Phillips 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Kant, Fichte, Later modern philosophy, General
philosophy of science, philosophy of biology, philosophy of mind, epistemology,
metaethics and metaphilosophy.  
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Helen Robertson <br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Kant, History of Modern Philosophy,
  Metaphysics.
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Joshua Rowlands<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Kant, History of Modern Philosophy,
  Metaphysics.
</td>

<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Penelope Rowlatt<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of Mind, Political
  Philosophy
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Josephine Salverda<br /> <br /> 
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong>Philosophy of Mathematics,
  Epistemology and Philosophy of Science.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Current research:</strong> I am working towards an
  account of explanation in mathematics.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td class="align-left">
  Ashley Shaw<br /><br />
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  <p class="p"><strong>Interests: </strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Philosophy of Mind and Philosophy of Language</strong>: I am interested in the content, ascription and
epistemology of neglected psychological attitudes (e.g. non-representational
attitudes like desire, non-propositional attitudes, de se attitudes). My
research has led me to think about interrogatives and imperatives in natural
language. I am also interested in how these attitudes interact, the nature of
attitudinal conflict or inconsistency, and associated issues like Moore’s
Paradox.</p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  Laura Silva

  special focus on contractualist theories developed by Rawls and Scanlon,

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Research Key Contacts</h1>
<p class="p">The <strong>Graduate Programme Administrator</strong>, Richard Edwards, is the first point of contact for all general enquiries about the MPhil Stud, MPhil/PhD and PhD programmes in the Philosophy Department.</p>
<p class="p">The <strong>Graduate Tutor</strong>, Dr Rory Madden (term 1) or Dr Fiona Leigh (terms 2 &amp; 3), is the first point of contact about supervision requests, module choices (MPhil Stud and MPhil/PhD) as well as general pastoral help.</p>
<p class="p">Research students have a primary and secondary <strong>supervisor</strong> assigned. The primary supervisor in Portico is taken to be the member of academic staff who has overall supervisory responsibility in relation to your graduate research. You will also be assigned a secondary supervisor on Portico, and this is ideally a member of staff who will supervise your research for a term on a regular but occasional basis. Each term you will be assigned just one supervisor (your ‘term’ supervisor) to work with for that term listed <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/research-programmes" target="_self">here</a>.</p>
<p class="p">Research students can also contact their <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/staff-student-consultative-committee" target="_blank">student academic representative <strong>(StAR)</strong></a> about matters they would like discussed at the staff-student consultative committee. </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      http://www.ucl.ac.uk/philosophy/current-students/research-programmes/mphil-courses
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
